item.title: 【My first KubeCon + CloudNativeCon: A journey through community, inclusivity, and neurodiversity】我的第一次 KubeCon + CloudNativeCon：社区、包容性和神经多样性之旅
item.description:
【

Stepping into my first KubeCon + CloudNativeCon, held this year in November in Atlanta, Georgia, felt like entering a world I had been following from afar for years; a world full of brilliant minds, bold ideas, and a shared dedication to building a more open and inclusive cloud-native ecosystem. What made this experience even more meaningful was navigating it as a neurodivergent person and discovering spaces where people like me not only belong but are celebrated.

Finding my place in the community

KubeCon + CloudNativeCon is often talked about as a conference but in reality, it’s a community gathering. Since Day 1 the OpenTelemetry Observatory was filled with conversations of contributors and maintainers to which I participated, and it felt like a safe space for me.

Celebrating the OpenTelemetry community

One of the most unforgettable moments of the week was receiving the 2025 OpenTelemetry Community Award. This recognition wasn’t just about my personal contributions, it was a reflection of the support, encouragement and generosity of a community that thrives on collaboration.

The award reminded me of why open source matters: because it’s built by people who care.

Embracing Merge Forward

A particularly powerful part of my KubeCon journey was engaging with the Merge Forward initiative. Merge Forward is a CNCF Technical Community Group made up of several subgroups, including Deaf & Hard of Hearing, Blind & Visually Impaired, Stuttering & Speech Diversity, Women in Cloud Native, Deep Roots, Friends of Dorothy and Neurodiversity. Its mission is to build supportive networks and safe spaces where underrepresented communities and their allies can come together to learn, mentor, grow, and simply be themselves.

Merge Forward provides a safe place for people to share experiences, find community, and ask for help without judgment. But we cannot do this alone; we need allies. True inclusion happens when those with privilege and visibility help amplify voices, remove barriers, and stand beside us in rooms where we might otherwise be overlooked.

I want to give a heartfelt thank-you to Catherine Paganini, the Co-Founder of Merge-Forward initiative, her vision and commitment helped bring Merge Forward to life and ensure that many voices, including neurodivergent ones like mine, are seen and supported.

Introducing Merge Forward to the industry

Another highlight was joining the Merge Forward initiative on the SiliconANGLE & theCUBE livestream, alongside Savannah Peterson and Jay Jackson from the Deaf & Hard of Hearing group. We talked openly about accessibility, community building, and how empowering underrepresented groups leads to stronger innovation.

Later in the week, I introduced the Merge Forward and Neurodiversity groups on stage as part of Ryan’s “Agile Brain” talk, a moment that meant more to me than I expected. Speaking publicly as a neurodivergent person, in a space historically dominated by conformity and perfectionism, felt like a step toward normalizing experiences like mine.

Merge Forward’s mission is simple: amplify voices, strengthen allyship, and build bridges across the CNCF ecosystem. And KubeCon + CloudNativeCon proved just how needed this work is.

Tips for neurodiverse folks attending their first (or next) KubeCon + CloudNativeCon

Attending a large, high-energy conference can be overwhelming, so here are a few suggestions that helped me navigate my first KubeCon + CloudNativeCon:

  • Create your own pace. You don’t have to attend every session. Pick what excites you and allow breaks between activities.
  • Find quiet spaces. Many conference venues have quiet corners or designated calm areas where you can decompress.
  • Schedule downtime intentionally. Even 10 minutes of silence can reset your energy for the next conversation.
  • Use tools that work for you. Noise-canceling headphones, fidget tools, note-taking apps, stim toys — anything that helps you self-regulate is valid.
  • Connect in ways that feel safe. You don’t need to network in crowded hallways. Smaller meetups, Pavilion areas, and project kiosks can be more manageable.
  • Bring a buddy if possible. Having someone who understands your needs can help reduce anxiety and avoid overstimulation.
  • Advocate for yourself. If you need a moment, a pause, clarification, or accommodation — you’re allowed to ask.

Connecting, collaborating, and welcoming new voices

Throughout the event, the Merge Forward Pavilion kiosk became a small but vibrant hub where people stopped by to ask questions, share their stories, and become part of a growing movement. The panel discussion brought together perspectives from newcomers, long-time contributors, and allies all focused on creating a more accessible and inclusive future in open source.

For me, these interactions were profoundly energizing. Networking at KubeCon + CloudNativeCon  wasn’t just exchanging business cards; it was about finding people who care about kindness, representation, and community as much as they care about code.

A neurodivergent perspective

Navigating a large, loud, high-energy conference isn’t always easy when you’re neurodivergent. The constant motion, tightly packed schedule, and sensory overwhelm can be challenging. But what stood out at KubeCon + CloudNativeCon was how many people, speakers, volunteers, contributors, and organizers made space for conversations about mental health, inclusion, and accessibility.

Being open about my neurodivergence felt empowering rather than limiting. Instead of hiding parts of myself, I found room to share them.

Looking forward: An invitation to join us

KubeCon + CloudNativeCon  taught me that the cloud-native community is at its strongest when we bring our full selves to the table. Inclusivity isn’t a checkbox; it’s a commitment that requires care, openness, and action.

If you’ve ever felt unsure about entering the open-source world whether because of neurodivergence, disability, imposter syndrome, or simply feeling different I want you to know that there is space for you here. The Merge Forward initiative is always looking for new contributors, allies, and curious minds who want to help build a more accessible future.

Closing thoughts

My first KubeCon + CloudNativeCon  wasn’t just a professional milestone, it was a deeply personal one.

Open source thrives when we all thrive. And I can’t wait to continue this work with an even larger and more diverse community next year.

If you’re interested in joining Merge Forward, supporting neurodiverse contributors, or getting involved in CNCF community groups, I invite you to reach out, sign up, and be part of something meaningful.

Resources

Merge-Forward CNCF initiative: https://community.cncf.io/merge-forward/

Neurodiversity: https://community.cncf.io/neurodiversity/

Deaf and Hard of Hearing: https://community.cncf.io/deaf-and-hard-of-hearing/

Blind and Visually Impaired: https://community.cncf.io/blind-and-visually-impaired/

Stuttering and Speech Diversity: https://community.cncf.io/stuttering-and-speech-diversity/

Women in Cloud Native: https://community.cncf.io/women-in-cloud-native/

Deep Roots: https://community.cncf.io/deep-roots/

Friends of Dorothy: https://community.cncf.io/friends-of-dorothy/ 

】

踏入今年 11 月在佐治亚州亚特兰大举行的我的第一次 KubeCon + CloudNativeCon，感觉就像进入了一个我多年来一直在远方关注的世界；这是一个充满聪明才智、大胆想法和共同致力于构建更加开放和包容的云原生生态系统的世界。让这次经历变得更有意义的是，作为一个神经分歧的人来探索它，并发现像我这样的人不仅属于而且值得庆祝的空间。

在社区中找到自己的位置

KubeCon + CloudNativeCon 通常被认为是一次会议，但实际上，这是一次社区聚会。自第一天起，OpenTelemetry Observatory 就充满了我参与的贡献者和维护者的对话，这对我来说就像一个安全的空间。

庆祝 OpenTelemetry 社区

本周最难忘的时刻之一是获得 2025 年 OpenTelemetry 社区奖。这种认可不仅仅是我个人的贡献，它反映了一个在协作中蓬勃发展的社区的支持、鼓励和慷慨。

该奖项提醒我为什么开源很重要：因为它是由关心的人构建的。

拥抱向前合并

我的 KubeCon 之旅中一个特别重要的部分是参与 Merge Forward 计划。 Merge Forward 是一个 CNCF 技术社区小组，由多个小组组成，包括聋哑人士和听力障碍人士、盲人和视力障碍人士、口吃和言语多样性、云原生女性、Deep Roots、Dorothy 之友和 Neurodiversity。其使命是建立支持性网络和安全空间，让代表性不足的社区及其盟友能够参与其中聚集在一起学习、指导、成长并简单地做自己。

Merge Forward 为人们提供了一个安全的场所，可以分享经验、寻找社区并寻求帮助，而无需做出判断。但我们不能单独做到这一点；我们需要盟友。当那些拥有特权和知名度的人帮助放大声音、消除障碍并站在我们身边，否则我们可能会被忽视时，真正的包容就会发生。

我要向 Merge-Forward 计划的联合创始人凯瑟琳·帕格尼尼 (Catherine Paganini) 表示衷心的感谢，她的远见和承诺帮助实现了 Merge Forward，并确保许多声音（包括像我这样的神经分歧者）得到关注和支持。

向行业介绍 Merge Forward

另一个亮点是与聋人和听力障碍团体的 Savannah Peterson 和 Jay Jackson 一起加入 SiliconANGLE 和 theCUBE 直播中的 Merge Forward 计划。我们公开讨论了可访问性、社区建设以及如何为代表性不足的群体赋权以带来更强大的创新。

Merge Forward 的使命很简单：放大声音、加强盟友关系并在 CNCF 生态系统之间架起桥梁。 KubeCon + CloudNativeCon 证明了这项工作的必要性。

为神经多元化人士参加第一次（或下一次）KubeCon + CloudNativeCon 的提示

参加大型、高强度的会议可能会让人不知所措，因此这里有一些建议可以帮助我顺利完成我的第一次 KubeCon + CloudNativeCon：

  • 制定自己的节奏。您不必参加每场课程。选择让您兴奋的事情，并在活动之间留出休息时间。
  • 寻找安静的空间。许多会议场所都有安静的角落或指定的安静区域，供您减压。
  • 有意识地安排休息时间。即使是 10 分钟的沉默也可以让您恢复精力以进行下一次对话。
  • 使用适合您的工具。降噪耳机、烦躁工具、记笔记应用、刺激玩具 - 任何可以帮助您自我调节的东西都有效。
  • 以安全的方式进行联系。您无需在拥挤的走廊中建立联系。较小的聚会、展馆区域和项目信息亭可以更易于管理。
  • 如果可能，请带上一个伙伴。有人了解您的需求有助于减少焦虑并避免过度刺激。
  • 为自己辩护。如果您需要一点时间、暂停、澄清或通融 - 您可以提出要求。

联系、协作并欢迎新声音

在整个活动期间，Merge Forward Pavilion 亭成为一个虽小但充满活力的中心，人们停下来提出问题，分享他们的故事，并成为不断发展的运动的一部分。小组讨论汇集了新来者、长期贡献者和盟友的观点，他们都专注于在开源领域创造一个更容易访问和更具包容性的未来。

对我来说，这些互动极大地激发了我的活力。 KubeCon + CloudNativeCon 上的交流不仅仅是交换名片；而是交流。这是为了找到像关心代码一样关心善良、代表性和社区的人。

神经发散的观点

当您的神经发散时，驾驭一场大型、喧闹、高能量的会议并不总是那么容易。持续不断的运动、紧凑的日程安排和感官上的压倒可能具有挑战性。但 KubeCon + CloudNativeCon 上最引人注目的是有多少人、演讲者、志愿者、贡献者和组织者为有关心理健康、包容性和可访问性的对话提供了空间。

对我的神经分歧持开放态度感觉是一种力量，而不是限制。我没有隐藏自己的一部分，而是找到了分享它们的空间。

展望：加入我们的邀请

KubeCon + CloudNativeCon 告诉我，当我们充分展现自我时，云原生社区就会变得最强大。包容性不是一个复选框；而是一个复选框。这是一个需要关怀、开放和行动的承诺。

如果您曾经对进入开源世界感到不确定，无论是因为神经分歧、残疾、冒名顶替综合症，还是只是感觉与众不同，我想让您知道这里有您的空间。 Merge Forward 计划始终在寻找新的贡献者、盟友和好奇心，帮助建设更容易实现的未来。

结束语

我的第一次 KubeCon + CloudNativeCon 不仅仅是一个职业里程碑，也是一个深刻的个人里程碑。

当我们都蓬勃发展时，开源就会蓬勃发展。我迫不及待地想明年与更大、更多元化的社区继续这项工作。

如果您有兴趣加入 Merge Forward、支持 Neurodiverse 贡献者或参与 CNCF 社区团体，我邀请您联系、注册并参与一些有意义的活动。

item.title: 【A guide to restarting pods in Kubernetes using kubectl】使用 kubectl 在 Kubernetes 中重新启动 pod 的指南
item.description:
【

This Member Blog was originally published on the Middleware blog and is republished here with permission.

kubectl is the command-line interface for managing Kubernetes clusters. It allows you to manage pods, deployments, and other resources from the terminal, helping you troubleshoot Kubernetes issues., check pod health, and scale applications easily. Most kubectl commands follow a simple structure.

For example, kubectl get pods lists running pods, and kubectl delete pod <pod-name> removes a pod.

Many users wonder how to restart a Kubernetes pod using kubectl. Contrary to popular belief, there is no direct kubectl restart pod command. Instead, Kubernetes expects you to work with higher-level objects, such as Deployments.

This guide covers the safest and most effective methods for restarting pods, including rollout restarts, deleting pods, scaling replicas, and updating environment variables, helping you manage pod restarts in a predictable and controlled way.

When should you restart a Kubernetes pod?

Knowing when to restart a Kubernetes pod is key to maintaining application stability and performance. Here are the most common scenarios that require a pod restart:

1. Configuration changes

When you update your application’s settings (such as environment variables or resource limits), the pod continues to use the old configurations. Restarting ensures the new settings take effect.

2. Recover from application failure

If your app crashes but the container stays in a “Running” state, or the pod shows as running but isn’t functioning, a restart forces a clean start to recover the service.

3. Debugging application issues

Restarting the pod helps resolve temporary issues or confirms persistent problems while troubleshooting why the application isn’t behaving as expected.

4. Pod stuck or not responding

A pod may stop responding to traffic while Kubernetes still reports it as healthy. Restarting resolves frozen states or resource leaks and restores responsiveness.

What are the different pod states in Kubernetes?

Understanding the different Kubernetes pod states enables you to monitor your application’s health and take the necessary actions when needed. Here are the key pod states you should know:

1. Pending

Kubernetes has approved the pod, but it is awaiting scheduling and launch. This occurs while Kubernetes is downloading container images or while it is still looking for a suitable node to run your pod. A prolonged pending pod typically indicates a configuration issue or insufficient resources.

2. Running

Your pod has at least one active container. The containers are working, but this doesn’t mean everything is functional. Your application may still have troubles despite the pod running.

3. Succeeded

You typically see this state with jobs or one-time tasks that are designed to run once and finish. It means all containers in the pod have completed their tasks successfully and won’t restart.

4. Failed

The failed state means one or more containers in the pod have stopped running, maybe due to an error, or the system terminated the containers. It indicates something went wrong with your application, or the container couldn’t restart correctly. Failed pods often need a restart.

5. Unknown

This indicates that the node where your pod should be running has lost contact with Kubernetes. Node failures, network problems, or other infrastructure issues may be the cause of this. It’s actually hard to tell what’s going on with your pod when you see this state.

How to restart pods in Kubernetes using kubectl

When you search for how to restart a Kubernetes pod using kubectl, the first thing that comes to mind is the command:

kubectl restart pod 

However, that command does not exist. Instead, there are several reliable methods to restart Kubernetes pods using kubectl. Below are the most effective and commonly used approaches:

1. Restart pods using Kubectl rollout restart

This is the commonly used method that follows Kubernetes best practices for restarting pods managed by a deployment. It performs a controlled restart without downtime by creating new pods and removing old ones.

Commands to use:

kubectl rollout restart deployment/my-app

This command replaces existing pods with new ones. It will remove the old pods after starting and waiting for the new ones. This approach keeps your app up during the restart.

To restart pods in a deployment within a specific namespace:

kubectl rollout restart deployment/my-app -n your-namespace

To check the status of your restart

kubectl rollout status deployment/my-app

Consider this strategy if you want minimal downtime, the safest alternative, or have deployment-managed pods.

2. Delete individual pods to force restart

With this method, you must delete pods to force Kubernetes to recreate them. It’s simpler than rollout restart, but you must watch which pods you remove.

If the pod is managed by a deployment, replica set, or equivalent controller, Kubernetes immediately creates a new one when you delete the existing one. However, this may temporarily disrupt service.

Here’s how to go about it:

# List all pods to see what you're working with

kubectl get pods

# To delete a specific pod

kubectl delete pod <pod-name>

# To delete multiple pods at once

kubectl delete pod <pod-1> <pod-2>

# To delete and wait to remove fully

kubectl delete pod <pod-name> --wait=true

# To force delete a stuck pod (use with caution)

kubectl delete pod <pod-name> --grace-period=0 --force

Delete only controller-managed pods. A standalone pod that isn’t managed by anything will never be restored if it is deleted.

3. Scale deployment replicas to restart pods

This strategy works by scaling your deployment down to zero replicas for a short time, which stops all the pods. Then it scales back up to the number you started with. Kubernetes lets you turn your program off and back again in a controlled way.

1. Check how many replicas you currently have

kubectl get deployment my-app

2. Scale down to zero

kubectl scale deployment my-app --replicas=0

3. Lastly, scale back up to your original number (creates new pods)

kubectl scale deployment my-app --replicas=3

When you scale down to zero, Kubernetes deletes all the pods in that deployment. When you scale back up, it creates new pods from scratch. This approach is more aggressive than rollout restart, but sometimes necessary when you need a complete fresh start.

4. Update environment variables to trigger a restart

This is yet another clever method for pod restarts. You will need to modify their configuration slightly. Kubernetes interprets changing environment variables in a deployment as a configuration change and restarts the pods automatically to implement the updated configuration.

The key here is that you don’t even have to alter your environment variables significantly. To initiate the restart, update a timestamp or add a dummy variable. 

For instance:

You can update an existing environment variable

kubectl set env deployment/my-app RESTART_TRIGGER=$(date +%s)

Or

You can also edit the deployment directly:

kubectl edit deployment my-app

Then add or modify any environment variable in the editor.

The benefit of using this approach is that it follows the same safe strategy as the rollout restart, and there’s no downtime during the restart process.

5. Replacing pods manually

Using the same configuration or an updated version, this method requires deleting particular pods and then manually creating new ones to replace them. You have total control over the creation and deletion processes with this method.

1. Get the pod configuration and save it

kubectl get pod -o yaml > pod-backup.yaml

2. Delete the existing pod

kubectl delete pod 

3. Create a new pod using the saved configuration

kubectl apply -f pod-backup.yaml

This method causes downtime because the old pod is removed before the new one starts. This method is only used with standalone pods; don’t do this with pods managed by deployments.

Conclusion

Restarting Kubernetes pods can help you in several practical ways, as discussed in this article, one of which is maintaining healthy applications. It doesn’t matter the method you choose to use; the key thing is to understand when and why you want to restart.

Monitoring pods also helps you in making the right restart decision. Instead of guessing what’s wrong, which you might be wrong about, proper observability shows you exactly when pods need attention.

】

kubectl 是用于管理 Kubernetes 集群的命令行界面。它允许您从终端管理 Pod、部署和其他资源，帮助您解决 Kubernetes 问题、检查 Pod 运行状况并轻松扩展应用程序。大多数 kubectl 命令都遵循简单的结构。

例如，kubectl get pods 列出正在运行的 pod，kubectl delete pod 删除 pod。

许多用户想知道如何使用 kubectl 重新启动 Kubernetes Pod。与普遍的看法相反，没有直接的 kubectl restart pod 命令。相反，Kubernetes 希望您使用更高级别的对象，例如部署。

本指南涵盖了最安全、最有效的 pod 重启方法，包括部署重启、删除 pod、扩展副本和更新环境变量，帮助您以可预测、可控的方式管理 pod 重启。

什么时候应该重启 Kubernetes Pod？

了解何时重新启动 Kubernetes Pod 是维持应用程序稳定性和性能的关键。以下是需要重新启动 Pod 的最常见场景：

1.配置更改

当您更新应用程序的设置（例如环境变量或资源限制）时，Pod 会继续使用旧配置。重新启动可确保新设置生效。

2.从应用程序故障中恢复

如果您的应用程序崩溃但容器仍处于“正在运行”状态，或者 Pod 显示为正在运行但未运行，则重新启动会强制重新启动以恢复服务。

3.调试应用程序问题

重新启动 Pod 有助于解决临时问题或确认持续存在的问题，同时排除应用程序未按预期运行的原因。

4. Pod 卡住或没有响应

pod 可能会停止响应流量，而 Kubernetes 仍将其报告为健康。重新启动可以解决冻结状态或资源泄漏并恢复响应能力。

Kubernetes 中有哪些不同的 pod 状态？

了解不同的 Kubernetes Pod 状态使您能够监控应用程序的运行状况并在需要时采取必要的操作。以下是您应该了解的关键 Pod 状态：

1.待处理

Kubernetes 已批准该 Pod，但正在等待调度和启动。当 Kubernetes 下载容器映像或仍在寻找合适的节点来运行 pod 时，会发生这种情况。长时间挂起的 pod 通常表示存在配置问题或 insuf资源充足。

2.正在运行

您的 Pod 至少有一个活动容器。容器正在工作，但这并不意味着一切都正常。尽管 Pod 正在运行，您的应用程序可能仍然存在问题。

3.成功

您通常会在设计为运行一次并完成的作业或一次性任务中看到这种状态。这意味着 Pod 中的所有容器都已成功完成任务，并且不会重新启动。

4.失败

失败状态意味着 Pod 中的一个或多个容器已停止运行，可能是由于错误，或者系统终止了容器。它表明您的应用程序出现问题，或者容器无法正确重新启动。失败的 Pod 通常需要重新启动。

5.未知

这表明您的 pod 应该运行的节点已与 Kubernetes 失去联系。节点故障、网络问题或其他基础设施问题可能是造成这种情况的原因。当您看到这种状态时，实际上很难判断您的 pod 发生了什么情况。

如何使用 kubectl 重启 Kubernetes 中的 Pod

当您搜索如何使用 kubectl 重新启动 Kubernetes pod 时，首先想到的是命令：

kubectl 重新启动 pod

但是，该命令不存在。相反，有几种可靠的方法可以使用 kubectl 重新启动 Kubernetes Pod。以下是最有效和最常用的方法：

1.使用 Kubectl rollout restart 重新启动 Pod

这是遵循 Kubernetes 最佳实践的常用方法，用于重新启动由部署管理的 Pod。它通过创建新 Pod 和删除旧 Pod 来执行受控重启，无需停机。

使用命令：

kubectl 部署重启部署/my-app

此命令将现有 Pod 替换为新 Pod。它会在启动并等待新的 pod 后删除旧的 pod。此方法使您的应用程序在重新启动期间保持正常运行。

要在特定命名空间内的部署中重新启动 Pod：

kubectl 推出重新启动部署/my-app -n your-namespace

检查重新启动的状态

kubectl 部署状态部署/my-app

如果您想要最短的停机时间、最安全的替代方案或拥有部署管理的 Pod，请考虑此策略。

2.删除单个 Pod 以强制重启

使用此方法，您必须删除 Pod 才能强制 Kubernetes 重新创建它们。比rollo简单ut 重新启动，但您必须注意删除了哪些 pod。

如果 Pod 由部署、副本集或等效控制器管理，则当您删除现有容器时，Kubernetes 会立即创建一个新容器。但是，这可能会暂时中断服务。

具体操作方法如下：

# 列出所有 pod 以查看您正在使用的内容

kubectl 获取 Pod

# 删除特定的pod

kubectl 删除 pod 

# 一次删除多个 Pod

kubectl 删除 pod  

# 删除并等待完全删除

kubectl delete pod  --wait=true

# 强制删除卡住的 pod（谨慎使用）

kubectl 删除 pod  --grace-period=0 --force

仅删除控制器管理的 Pod。不受任何管理的独立 Pod 被删除后将永远无法恢复。

3.扩展部署副本以重新启动 Pod

此策略的工作原理是在短时间内将部署缩减至零副本，从而停止所有 Pod。然后它会缩小到您开始时的数字。 Kubernetes 允许您以受控方式关闭程序并再次打开。

1.检查您当前拥有多少个副本

kubectl 获取部署 my-app

2.缩小到零

kubectl 规模部署 my-app --replicas=0

3.最后，缩小到原来的数量（创建新的 Pod）

kubectl 规模部署 my-app --replicas=3

当您缩小到零时，Kubernetes 会删除该部署中的所有 Pod。当您扩大规模时，它会从头开始创建新的 Pod。这种方法比部署重新启动更积极，但有时当您需要完全全新的开始时是必要的。

4.更新环境变量以触发重新启动

这是另一种巧妙的 Pod 重启方法。您将需要稍微修改它们的配置。 Kubernetes 将部署中环境变量的更改解释为配置更改，并自动重新启动 Pod 以实施更新的配置。

这里的关键是您甚至不必显着改变环境变量。要启动重新启动，请更新时间戳或添加虚拟变量。 

例如：

您可以更新现有的环境变量

kubectl 设置环境部署/我的应用 RESTART_TRIGGER=$(date +%s)

或者

您还可以直接编辑部署：

kubectl 编辑部署 my-app

然后在编辑器中添加或修改任何环境变量。

是使用这种方法的好处是它遵循与部署重启相同的安全策略，并且在重启过程中没有停机时间。

5.手动更换 Pod

使用相同的配置或更新的版本，此方法需要删除特定的 Pod，然后手动创建新的 Pod 来替换它们。使用此方法，您可以完全控制创建和删除过程。

1.获取pod配置并保存

kubectl get pod -o yaml > pod-backup.yaml

2.删除现有的 Pod

kubectl 删除 pod

3.使用保存的配置创建一个新的 Pod

kubectl apply -f pod-backup.yaml

此方法会导致停机，因为旧 Pod 在新 Pod 启动之前已被删除。此方法仅适用于独立 Pod；不要对部署管理的 Pod 执行此操作。

结论

重新启动 Kubernetes Pod 可以通过多种实用方式为您提供帮助，如本文所述，其中之一就是维护健康的应用程序。您选择使用哪种方法并不重要；关键是要了解何时以及为何要重新启动。

监控 Pod 还可以帮助您做出正确的重启决定。适当的可观察性可以准确地向您显示 Pod 何时需要关注，而不是猜测出了什么问题（您可能会错）。

item.title: 【runc container breakout vulnerabilities: A technical overview】runc 容器突破漏洞：技术概述
item.description:
【

A set of high-severity vulnerabilities in runc were publicly disclosed in November 2025, allowing for full container breakouts. Runc is the cornerstone of containerization on Linux, serving as the default low-level container runtime for industry-standard tools like Docker, Podman, and Kubernetes. Its ubiquity means that a vulnerability in runc has far-reaching implications for the entire cloud-native ecosystem. This post summarizes the vulnerabilities, the affected versions, and the recommended actions to mitigate them.

The vulnerabilities

Three vulnerabilities were discovered, all related to bypassing runc’s restrictions on writing to arbitrary /proc files. These vulnerabilities can be exploited by starting containers with custom mount configurations, including those defined in Dockerfiles (RUN –mount=…).

CVE-2025-31133: “container escape via ‘masked path’ abuse due to mount race conditions”

CVSS: 7.3 

Description: This vulnerability exploits an issue with how masked paths are implemented. An attacker can replace /dev/null with a symlink to a procfs file (e.g., /proc/sys/kernel/core_pattern or /proc/sysrq-trigger). Runc will then bind-mount the symlink target read-write, leading to a container breakout or a host crash.

CVE-2025-52565: “container escape with malicious config due to /dev/console mount and related races”

CVSS: 7.3 

Description: Similar to the previous CVE, this vulnerability exploits a flaw in /dev/console bind-mounts. By replacing /dev/pts/$n with a symlink, an attacker can get runc to bind-mount the symlink target over /dev/console, allowing read-write access to sensitive procfs files.

CVE-2025-52881: “container escape and denial of service due to arbitrary write gadgets and procfs write redirects”

CVSS: 7.3 

Description: This is a more sophisticated vulnerability that bypasses LSM (Linux Security Modules) checks. An attacker can make /proc/self/attr/<label> reference a real procfs file, which can be used to redirect writes to malicious targets like /proc/sysrq-trigger (host crash) or /proc/sys/kernel/core_pattern (full container breakout).

Exploitation scenarios and threat model

These vulnerabilities could be abused in real-world setups where a user can run a container from a malicious or compromised image. For example, a multi-tenant environment where users can define their own containers could be at risk. An attacker could craft a Dockerfile with a malicious RUN –mount=… instruction that, when built and run, would trigger one of these vulnerabilities and allow them to escape the container and gain control of the underlying host.

Kubernetes and cloud native implications

In a Kubernetes environment, the impact of these vulnerabilities is magnified.

A successful exploit could allow an attacker to escape a container and potentially gain access to the node’s kubelet, which would give them control over all other pods running on that node. From there, they could potentially compromise the entire cluster. This is why it is critical for all Kubernetes users to update their container runtimes as soon as possible.

Affected versions and patches

Users are strongly recommended to update to one of the following runc releases as soon as possible:

runc v1.4.0-rc.3

runc v1.3.3

runc v1.2.8

Mitigations

Besides upgrading runc, the following mitigations can be applied:

  • User namespaces: Use user namespaces with the host root user not mapped into the container’s namespace.
  • Non-root user: Do not run as a root user in the container.
  • AppArmor/SELinux: While not a complete solution, using AppArmor and SELinux can help to mitigate some of the attack vectors.

It’s also important to note that the real-world impact of these vulnerabilities is significantly reduced in environments that follow security best practices. If you are using a controlled set of hardened and secured container images and you monitor your deployments with CI/CD pipelines for security and linting controls, the risk of exploitation is much lower. These vulnerabilities are most critical in scenarios where untrusted or unvetted container images can be introduced and run.

The bigger picture: Secure-by-default configurations

These vulnerabilities highlight the need for secure-by-default configurations for container runtimes. The OpenSSF and the Open Container Initiative (OCI) are working on standardizing such configurations to reduce the attack surface and prevent similar vulnerabilities in the future. This is an ongoing effort, and it is crucial for the community to get involved and contribute to these initiatives.

Other Container Runtimes

Other container runtimes like youki and crun are also understood to have similar flaws and are working on patches. Users of other runtimes should check for security updates from their vendors.

Credits

Credits for the discovery of these vulnerabilities go to:

Lei Wang (@ssst0n3 from Huawei)

Li Fubang (@lifubang from acmcoder.com, CIIC)

Tõnis Tiigi (@tonistiigi from Docker)

Aleksa Sarai (@cyphar from SUSE)

】

runc 中的一组高严重性漏洞于 2025 年 11 月公开披露，允许完整容器突破。 Runc 是 Linux 上容器化的基石，作为 Docker、Podman 和 Kubernetes 等行业标准工具的默认低级容器运行时。它的普遍存在意味着 runc 中的漏洞会对整个云原生生态系统产生深远的影响。这篇文章总结了这些漏洞、受影响的版本以及缓解这些漏洞的建议操作。

漏洞

发现了三个漏洞，所有这些漏洞都与绕过 runc 对写入任意 /proc 文件的限制有关。可以通过使用自定义安装配置启动容器来利用这些漏洞，包括 Dockerfile 中定义的配置 (RUN –mount=...)。

CVE-2025-31133：“由于安装竞争条件，容器通过滥用‘屏蔽路径’逃逸”

CVSS：7.3

描述：此漏洞利用了如何实现屏蔽路径的问题。攻击者可以将 /dev/null 替换为 procfs 文件的符号链接（例如 /proc/sys/kernel/core_pattern 或 /proc/sysrq-trigger）。然后，Runc 将绑定挂载符号链接目标读写，导致容器崩溃或主机崩溃。

CVE-2025-52565：“由于 /dev/console 挂载和相关竞争，容器通过恶意配置逃逸”

CVSS：7.3

描述：与之前的 CVE 类似，该漏洞利用了 /dev/console 绑定挂载中的缺陷。通过用符号链接替换 /dev/pts/$n ，攻击者可以让 runc 在 /dev/console 上绑定挂载符号链接目标，从而允许对敏感的 procfs 文件进行读写访问。

CVE-2025-52881：“由于任意写入小工具和 procfs 写入重定向而导致容器逃逸和拒绝服务”

CVSS：7.3

描述：这是一个更复杂的漏洞，可以绕过 LSM（Linux 安全模块）检查。攻击者可以使 /proc/self/attr/

利用场景和威胁模型

这些漏洞可能在现实世界的设置中被滥用，用户可以从恶意或受损的映像运行容器。例如，用户可以定义自己的容器的多租户环境可能面临风险。攻击者可以使用恶意 RUN –mount=... 指令制作 Dockerfile，该指令在构建并运行时会触发其中一个漏洞，并允许他们逃离容器并获得对底层主机的控制。

Kubernetes 和云原生影响

在 Kubernetes 环境中，这些漏洞的影响被放大。

成功的利用可能允许攻击者逃离容器并可能获得对节点 kubelet 的访问权限，这将使他们能够控制该节点上运行的所有其他 Pod。从那里，他们可能会危害整个集群。这就是为什么所有 Kubernetes 用户尽快更新其容器运行时至关重要。

受影响的版本和补丁

强烈建议用户尽快更新到以下 runc 版本之一：

runc v1.4.0-rc.3

runc v1.3.3

runc v1.2.8

缓解措施

除了升级 runc 之外，还可以应用以下缓解措施：

  • 用户命名空间：使用用户命名空间，主机 root 用户未映射到容器的命名空间。
  • 非 root 用户：不要在容器中以 root 用户身份运行。
  • AppArmor/SELinux：虽然不是完整的解决方案，但使用 AppArmor 和 SELinux 可以帮助减轻一些攻击媒介。

还需要注意的是，在遵循安全最佳实践的环境中，这些漏洞的实际影响会显着降低。如果您使用一组受控的强化且安全的容器映像，并使用 CI/CD 管道监控部署以实现安全性和 linting 控制，则被利用的风险会低得多。在可以引入和运行不受信任或未经审查的容器映像的场景中，这些漏洞最为严重。

大局：默认安全配置

这些漏洞凸显了容器运行时默认安全配置的必要性。 OpenSSF 和开放容器计划 (OCI) 正在致力于标准化此类配置，以减少攻击面并防止未来出现类似漏洞。这是一项持续的努力，社区参与并为这些举措做出贡献至关重要。

其他容器运行时

据了解，youki 和 crun 等其他容器运行时也存在类似缺陷，并且正在修复补丁。其他运行时的用户应检查其供应商的安全更新。

制作人员

发现这些漏洞的功劳如下：

李福邦（@lifubang，来自 acmcoder.com，CIIC）

Tõnis Tiigi（来自 Docker 的 @tonistiigi）
