item.title: 【From chaos to clarity: How OpenTelemetry unified observability across clouds】从混乱到清晰：OpenTelemetry 如何统一跨云的可观测性
item.description:
【

Modern applications rarely live in a single place anymore. One organization’s application footprint was spread across AWS, Azure, and GCP, with some workloads still running on-prem. This multi-cloud approach gave them resilience and flexibility, but it came with a hidden cost: observability sprawl.

Each cloud provider brought its own native observability stack. On AWS, they used CloudWatch; on Azure, Azure Monitor; on GCP, Stackdriver; and in their on-prem setup, a mix of Prometheus and ELK. Add to that some third-party APM tools, and suddenly engineers were juggling five dashboards just to debug one request.

This was slowing them down. Mean Time to Resolution (MTTR) kept climbing, and developers spent more time stitching together logs and traces than writing code.

The turning point came when the organization adopted OpenTelemetry (OTel), a CNCF graduated project and community-driven standard for observability. What started as a small experiment soon became the backbone of their observability strategy, aligning with the broader trend across the CNCF community toward platform engineering maturity and standardized telemetry practices..

The problem: Observability tool sprawl

Let’s break down what was happening before OpenTelemetry:

  • Multiple tools for the same purpose
    • Metrics: Prometheus (on-prem) + CloudWatch (AWS) + Azure Monitor (Azure).
    • Logs: ELK (on-prem) + Stackdriver (GCP).
    • Traces: A commercial APM tool.
  • Lack of end-to-end visibility
     A request starting in AWS Lambda, passing through an Azure-hosted API, and finally hitting a GCP database could not be traced seamlessly. Engineers saw fragments of the request but not the big picture.
  • Inconsistent instrumentation
     Each tool required its own SDKs and agents. This meant extra developer effort and inconsistencies in the telemetry data.
  • Vendor lock-in
     Switching tools or consolidating data required rewriting instrumentation—a huge blocker for modernization.

The result: fragmented visibility, longer outages, and frustrated engineers. This pattern mirrors what many CNCF end-user organizations have shared in TAG Observability discussions—growing complexity without a unified telemetry layer.

The turning point: Why OpenTelemetry

The organization needed a way to decouple instrumentation from backend tools. Enter OpenTelemetry.

OpenTelemetry is an open-source standard for collecting traces, metrics, and logs. As part of the CNCF ecosystem (alongside projects like Prometheus, Fluent Bit, and Jaeger) OTel provides:

  • Language SDKs for most major languages (Java, Python, Go, Node.js, .NET, etc.).
  • A Collector that receives telemetry, processes it, and exports it to any backend.
  • Semantic conventions to standardize telemetry across services.

In other words: instrument once, export anywhere.

The solution: Implementing OpenTelemetry

The migration happened in three phases.

1. Instrumenting applications

The team started by adding OTel SDKs to a few critical microservices. These SDKs automatically captured traces, metrics, and logs with minimal code changes. For example, in Python:

This snippet shows how an application can start sending traces to the OTel Collector.

2. Deploying the OTel Collector

The OpenTelemetry Collector became the heart of the system. Instead of sending telemetry directly to each vendor’s tool, apps now sent everything to the Collector.

The Collector handled:

  • Ingesting telemetry (via OTLP protocol).
  • Processing (adding metadata, sampling, filtering).

Exporting (to Prometheus, Jaeger, Grafana, Datadog, etc.).


Example configuration:

receivers:
  otlp:
    protocols:
      grpc:
      http:

exporters:
  prometheus:
    endpoint: "0.0.0.0:9464"
  jaeger:
    endpoint: "jaeger:14250"
    tls:
      insecure: true

service:
  pipelines:
    traces:
      receivers: [otlp]
      exporters: [jaeger]
    metrics:
      receivers: [otlp]
      exporters: [prometheus]

Now, apps didn’t care where the data went. The Collector handled routing.

3. Unified observability

With traces going into Jaeger and metrics into Prometheus, dashboards in Grafana became the single pane of glass.

 Before (tool chaos):

AWS → CloudWatch

Azure → Azure Monitor

GCP → Stackdriver

On-prem → Prometheus + ELK


After (OTel-powered):

Apps → OTel SDK → OTel Collector → [ Jaeger | Prometheus | Grafana ]

This was the “aha” moment. Engineers could now trace a request end-to-end, across AWS, Azure, and GCP, in a single view.

Benefits realized

The company saw immediate improvements:

  • Unified observability → no more jumping between dashboards.
  • Consistent data → telemetry looked the same regardless of cloud.
  • Faster MTTR → engineers could trace failures across services.
  • Flexibility → easy to switch from Jaeger to Datadog, or from Prometheus to CloudWatch, without touching application code.
  • Cost optimization → eliminated redundant tools and vendor lock-in.

These outcomes reflect broader community findings around the value of open standards in multi-cloud environments.

Lessons learned

  1. Start small: Instrument one service first, then expand.
  2. Use the OTel Collector: Don’t send telemetry directly to vendors.
  3. Adopt semantic conventions: Consistent naming makes analysis easier.
  4. Involve developers early: Good observability requires dev buy-in.

Treat observability as part of your platform engineering strategy, not a one-off tooling decision.

Conclusion

OpenTelemetry proved to be more than just a new observability framework for the company—it became the unifying layer that tied together a fragmented, multi-cloud ecosystem. What once felt like chaos—navigating multiple dashboards, struggling to correlate logs with metrics, and losing requests across cloud boundaries—was transformed into a cohesive, cloud-agnostic observability strategy.

By adopting OpenTelemetry:

  • Developers gained a single instrumentation standard that works across AWS, Azure, GCP, and on-prem systems.
  • Operations teams unlocked true end-to-end tracing, making it possible to follow a request seamlessly, whether it starts in AWS Lambda, passes through Azure API Gateway, or ends in GCP Cloud SQL.
  • Leadership saw reduced costs and vendor independence, with the freedom to choose (or switch) backends like Jaeger, Prometheus, Grafana, or Datadog without rewriting code.
  • The organization as a whole shortened Mean Time to Resolution (MTTR), enabling faster incident response and greater confidence in production.

The biggest win? Flexibility and future-proofing. OpenTelemetry allowed the organization to embrace multi-cloud without being tied to each provider’s observability ecosystem. Their developers could focus on building features instead of wrestling with telemetry, and their SRE/DevOps teams finally had a unified view of the system.

If your organization is grappling with tool sprawl and fragmented visibility across clouds, the CNCF observability ecosystem—including OpenTelemetry— can help you take back control. Start small, experiment with one service, and build from there. The payoff—a simplified, scalable, and vendor-neutral observability stack—is well worth the effort.

Instrument once. Observe anywhere. Own your observability journey.

】

现代应用程序很少再位于一个地方。一个组织的应用程序足迹分布在 AWS、Azure 和 GCP 上，一些工作负载仍在本地运行。这种多云方法为他们提供了弹性和灵活性，但也带来了隐性成本：可观测性蔓延。

每个云提供商都带来了自己的本机可观察性堆栈。在AWS上，他们使用了CloudWatch；在 Azure 上，Azure Monitor；在 GCP 上，Stackdriver；在他们的本地设置中，混合使用了Prometheus和ELK。再加上一些第三方 APM 工具，突然之间，工程师们不得不使用五个仪表板来调试一个请求。

这减慢了他们的速度。平均解决时间 (MTTR) 不断攀升，开发人员花在拼接日志和跟踪上的时间比编写代码的时间还要多。

当该组织采用了 OpenTelemetry (OTel)（CNCF 毕业项目和社区驱动的可观测性标准）时，转折点出现了。最初的一个小实验很快就成为了他们可观测性策略的支柱，与 CNCF 社区向平台工程成熟度和标准化遥测实践的更广泛趋势保持一致。

问题：可观察性工具蔓延

让我们分解一下 OpenTelemetry 之前发生的事情：

  • 多种工具用于同一目的
    • 指标：Prometheus（本地）+ CloudWatch (AWS) + Azure Monitor (Azure)。
    • 日志：ELK（本地）+ Stackdriver (GCP)。
    • Traces：商业 APM 工具。
  • 缺乏端到端可见性
    无法无缝跟踪从 AWS Lambda 开始、通过 Azure 托管的 API、最终到达 GCP 数据库的请求。工程师看到了请求的片段，但看不到大局。
  • 检测不一致
    每个工具都需要自己的 SDK 和代理。这意味着开发人员需要付出额外的努力，并且遥测数据会不一致。
  • 供应商锁定
    切换工具或整合数据需要重写工具——这是现代化的巨大障碍。

结果是：可见性分散、停机时间更长、工程师感到沮丧。这种模式反映了许多 CNCF 最终用户组织在 TAG 可观测性讨论中所分享的内容：如果没有统一的遥测层，复杂性就会增加。

转折点：为什么选择 OpenTelemetry

该组织需要一种将仪表与后端工具分离的方法。输入OpenTelemetry。

OpenTelemetry 是一个用于收集跟踪、指标和日志的开源标准。作为 CNCF 生态系统的一部分（以及 Prometheus、Fluent Bit 和 Jaeger 等项目），OTel 提供：

  • 语言 SDK，适用于大多数主要语言（Java、Python、Go、Node.js、.NET 等）。
  • 一个收集器，用于接收遥测数据、对其进行处理并将其导出到任何后端。
  • 语义约定，用于标准化跨服务的遥测。

换句话说：检测一次，导出到任何地方。

解决方案：实施 OpenTelemetry

迁移分三个阶段进行。

1.仪表应用

团队首先将OTel SDK添加到一些关键微服务中。这些 SDK 可自动捕获跟踪、指标和日志，只需最少的代码更改。例如，在 Python 中：

此代码段显示应用程序如何开始将跟踪发送到OTel Collector。

2.部署OTel收集器

OpenTelemetry Collector 成为系统的核心。应用程序现在将所有内容发送到收集器，而不是直接将遥测数据发送到每个供应商的工具。

收集器处理：

  • 接收遥测数据（通过 OTLP 协议）。
  • 处理（添加元数据、采样、过滤）。

导出（到 Prometheus、Jaeger、Grafana、Datadog 等）。


配置示例：

接收器：
  奥特普：
    协议：
      组组：
      http：

出口商：
  普罗米修斯：
    端点：“0.0.0.0:9464”
  耶格尔：
    端点：“jaeger：14250”
    :不安全：真实

服务：
  管道：
    痕迹：
      接收者：[otlp]
      出口商：[耶格]
    指标：
      接收者：[otlp]
      出口商：[普罗米修斯]

现在，应用程序并不关心数据去了哪里。收集器处理路由。

3.统一可观测性

随着跟踪进入 Jaeger 和指标进入 Prometheus，Grafana 中的仪表板成为单一管理面板。

 之前（工具混乱）：

AWS → CloudWatch

Azure → Azure 监视器

GCP → Stackdriver

本地 → Prometheus + ELK


之后（OTel 供电）：

应用程序 → OTel SDK → OTel Collector → [ Jaeger |普罗米修斯|格拉法纳]

这是“顿悟”时刻。工程师现在可以在单个视图中跨 AWS、Azure 和 GCP 端到端地跟踪请求。

实现的好处

公司立即取得了进步：

  • 统一的可观察性 → 仪表板之间不再跳转。
  • 数据一致 → 无论云如何，遥测看起来都是一样的。
  • 更快的 MTTR → 工程师可以跨服务跟踪故障。
  • 灵活性 → 轻松从 Jaeger 切换到 Datadog，或从 Prometheus 切换到 CloudWatch，无需触及应用程序代码。
  • 成本优化 → 消除了冗余工具和供应商锁定。

这些结果反映了关于多云环境中开放标准价值的更广泛的社区发现。

经验教训

  • 从小事做起：首先检测一项服务，然后再扩展。
  • 使用 OTel Collector：不要直接向供应商发送遥测数据。
  • 采用语义约定：一致的命名使分析更加容易。
  • 尽早让开发人员参与：良好的可观察性需要开发人员的支持。

    • 将可观察性视为平台工程策略的一部分，而不是一次性的工具决策。

    结论

    事实证明，OpenTelemetry 不仅仅是该公司的一个新的可观察性框架，它还成为将分散的多云生态系统联系在一起的统一层。曾经感觉混乱的情况（导航多个仪表板、努力将日志与指标关联起来以及跨云边界丢失请求）已经转变为有凝聚力的云与 d 无关的可观测性策略。

    通过采用 OpenTelemetry：

    • 开发人员获得了适用于 AWS、Azure、GCP 和本地系统的单一仪器标准。
    • 运营团队解锁了真正的端到端跟踪，使得无缝跟踪请求成为可能，无论请求是在 AWS Lambda 中开始、通过 Azure API Gateway 还是在 GCP Cloud SQL 中结束。
    • 领导层看到了成本降低和供应商独立性，可以自由选择（或切换）Jaeger、Prometheus、Grafana 或 Datadog 等后端，而无需重写代码。
    • 整个组织缩短了平均解决时间 (MTTR)，从而加快了事件响应速度并提高了生产信心。

    最大的胜利？灵活性和面向未来。 OpenTelemetry 使组织能够拥抱多云，而无需依赖于每个提供商的可观测性生态系统。他们的开发人员可以专注于构建功能，而不是忙于遥测，他们的 SRE/DevOps 团队最终对系统有了统一的视图。

    如果您的组织正在努力解决工具蔓延和跨云的分散可见性问题，CNCF 可观测性生态系统（包括 OpenTelemetry）可以帮助您夺回控制权。从小事做起，尝试一项服务，然后从那里开始构建。其回报是一个简化的、可扩展的、供应商中立的可观察性堆栈，这是非常值得的。

    仪器一次。随处观察。拥有您的可观察性旅程。

item.title: 【Announcing Kyverno release 1.16】宣布 Kyverno 版本 1.16
item.description:
【

Kyverno 1.16 delivers major advancements in policy as code for Kubernetes, centered on a new generation of CEL-based policies now available in beta with a clear path to GA. This release introduces partial support for namespaced CEL policies to confine enforcement and minimize RBAC, aligning with least-privilege best practices. Observability is significantly enhanced with full metrics for CEL policies and native event generation, enabling precise visibility and faster troubleshooting. Security and governance get sharper controls through fine-grained policy exceptions tailored for CEL policies, and validation use cases broaden with the integration of an HTTP authorizer into ValidatingPolicy. Finally, we’re debuting the Kyverno SDK, laying the foundation for ecosystem integrations and custom tooling.

CEL policy types

CEL policies in beta

CEL policy types are introduced as v1beta. The promotion plan provides a clear, non‑breaking path: v1 will be made available in 1.17 with GA targeted for 1.18. This release includes the cluster‑scoped family (Validating, Mutating, Generating, Deleting, ImageValidating) at v1beta1 and adds namespaced variants for validation, deleting, and image validation; namespaced Generating and Mutating will follow in 1.17. PolicyException and GlobalContextEntry will advance in step to keep versions aligned; see the promotion roadmap in this tracking issue.

Namespaced policies

Kyverno 1.16 introduces namespaced CEL policy types— NamespacedValidatingPolicy, NamespacedDeletingPolicy, and NamespacedImageValidatingPolicy—which mirror their cluster-scoped counterparts but apply only within the policy’s namespace. This lets teams enforce guardrails with least-privilege RBAC and without central changes, improving multi-tenancy and safety during rollout. Choose namespaced types for team-owned namespaces and cluster-scoped types for global controls.

Observability upgrades

CEL policies now have comprehensive, native observability for faster diagnosis:

  • Validating policy execution latency Metrics: kyverno_validating_policy_execution_duration_seconds_count, …_sum, …_bucket
    • What it measures: Time spent evaluating validating policies per admission/background execution as a Prometheus histogram. 
    • Key labels: policy_name, policy_background_mode, policy_validation_mode (enforce/audit), resource_kind, resource_namespace, resource_request_operation (create/update/delete), execution_cause (admission_request/background_scan), result (PASS/FAIL). 
  • Mutating policy execution latency: kyverno_mutating_policy_execution_duration_seconds_count, …_sum, …_bucket 
    • What it measures: Time spent executing mutating policies (admission/background) as a Prometheus histogram. 
    • Key labels: policy_name, policy_background_mode, resource_kind, resource_namespace, resource_request_operation, execution_cause, result. 
  • Generating policy execution latency Metrics: kyverno_generating_policy_execution_duration_seconds_count, …_sum, …_bucket
    • What it measures: Time spent executing generating policies when evaluating requests or during background scans. 
    • Key labels: policy_name, policy_background_mode, resource_kind, resource_namespace, resource_request_operation, execution_cause, result. 
  • Image-validating policy execution latency Metrics: kyverno_image_validating_policy_execution_duration_seconds_count, …_sum, …_bucket 
    • What it measures: Time spent evaluating image-related validating policies (e.g., image verification) as a Prometheus histogram. 
    • Key labels: policy_name, policy_background_mode, resource_kind, resource_namespace, resource_request_operation, execution_cause, result. 

CEL policies now emit Kubernetes Events for passes, violations, errors, and compile/load issues with rich context (policy/rule, resource, user, mode). This provides instant, kubectl-visible feedback and easier correlation with admission decisions and metrics during rollout and troubleshooting.

Fine-grained policy exceptions

Image-based exceptions

This exception allows Pods in ci using images, via images attribute, that match the provided patterns while keeping the no-latest rule enforced for all other images. It narrows the bypass to specific namespaces and teams for auditability. 

apiVersion: policies.kyverno.io/v1beta1
kind: PolicyException
metadata:
 name: allow-ci-latest-images
 namespace: ci
spec:
 policyRefs:
   - name: restrict-image-tag
     kind: ValidatingPolicy
 images:
   - "ghcr.io/kyverno/*:latest"
 matchConditions:
   - expression: "has(object.metadata.labels.team) && object.metadata.labels.team == 'platform'"

The following ValidatingPolicy references exceptions.allowedImages which skips validation checks for white-listed image(s):

apiVersion: policies.kyverno.io/v1beta1
kind: ValidatingPolicy
metadata:
name: restrict-image-tag
spec:
rules:
  - name: broker-config
    matchConstraints:
      resourceRules:
        - apiGroups:   [apps]
          apiVersions: [v1]
          operations:  [CREATE, UPDATE]
          resources:   [pods]
    validations:
     - message: "Containers must not allow privilege escalation unless they are in the allowed images list."
       expression: >
         object.spec.containers.all(container,
          string(container.image) in exceptions.allowedImages ||
          (
            has(container.securityContext) &&
            has(container.securityContext.allowPrivilegeEscalation) &&
            container.securityContext.allowPrivilegeEscalation == false
          )
        )

Value-based exceptions

This exception allows a list of values via allowedValues used by a CEL validation for a constrained set of targets so teams can proceed without weakening the entire policy.

apiVersion: policies.kyverno.io/v1beta1
kind: PolicyException
metadata:
 name: allow-debug-annotation
 namespace: dev
spec:
 policyRefs:
   - name: check-security-context
     kind: ValidatingPolicy
 allowedValues:
   - "debug-mode-temporary"
 matchConditions:
   - expression: "object.metadata.name.startsWith('experiments-')"

Here’s the policy leverages above allowed values. It denies resources unless the annotation value is present in exceptions.allowedValues.

apiVersion: policies.kyverno.io/v1beta1
kind: ValidatingPolicy
metadata:
 name: check-security-context
spec:
 matchConstraints:
   resourceRules:
   - apiGroups:   [apps]
     apiVersions: [v1]
     operations:  [CREATE, UPDATE]
     resources:   [deployments]
 variables:
   - name: allowedCapabilities
     expression: "['AUDIT_WRITE','CHOWN','DAC_OVERRIDE','FOWNER','FSETID','KILL','MKNOD','NET_BIND_SERVICE','SETFCAP','SETGID','SETPCAP','SETUID','SYS_CHROOT']"
 validations:
   - expression: >-
       object.spec.containers.all(container,
      container.?securityContext.?capabilities.?add.orValue([]).all(capability,
      capability in exceptions.allowedValues ||
      capability in variables.allowedCapabilities))
     message: >-
       Any capabilities added beyond the allowed list (AUDIT_WRITE, CHOWN, DAC_OVERRIDE, FOWNER,
      FSETID, KILL, MKNOD, NET_BIND_SERVICE, SETFCAP, SETGID, SETPCAP, SETUID, SYS_CHROOT)
      are disallowed.

Configurable reporting status 

This exception sets reportResult: pass, so when it matches, Policy Reports show “pass” rather than the default “skip”, improving dashboards and SLO signals during planned waivers.

apiVersion: policies.kyverno.io/v1beta1
kind: PolicyException
metadata:
 name: exclude-skipped-deployment-2
 labels:
   polex.kyverno.io/priority: "0.2"
spec:
 policyRefs:
 - name: "with-multiple-exceptions"
   kind: ValidatingPolicy
 matchConditions:
   - name: "check-name"
     expression: "object.metadata.name == 'skipped-deployment'"
 reportResult: pass

Kyverno Authz Server

Beyond enriching admission-time validation, Kyverno now extends policy decisions to your service edge. The Kyverno Authz Server applies Kyverno policies to authorize requests for Envoy (via the External Authorization filter) and for plain HTTP services as a standalone HTTP authorization server, returning allow/deny decisions based on the same policy engine you use in Kubernetes. This unifies policy enforcement across admission, gateways, and services, enabling consistent guardrails and faster adoption without duplicating logic. See the project page for details: kyverno/kyverno-authz.

Introducing the Kyverno SDK

Alongside embedding CEL policy evaluation in controllers, CLIs, and CI, there’s now a companion SDK for service-edge authorization. The SDK lets you load Kyverno policies, compile them, and evaluate incoming requests to produce allow/deny decisions with structured results—powering Envoy External Authorization and plain HTTP services without duplicating policy logic. It’s designed for gateways, sidecars, and app middleware with simple Go APIs, optional metrics/hooks, and a path to unify admission-time and runtime enforcement. Note that kyverno-authz is still in active development; start with non-critical paths and add strict timeouts as you evaluate. See the SDK package for details: kyverno SDK.

Other features and enhancements 

Label-based reporting configuration

Kyverno now supports label-based report suppression. Add the label reports.kyverno.io/disabled (any value, e.g., “true”) to any policy— ClusterPolicy, CEL policy types, ValidatingAdmissionPolicy, or MutatingAdmissionPolicy—to prevent all reporting (both ephemeral and PolicyReports) for that policy. This lets teams silence noisy or staging policies without changing enforcement; remove the label to resume reporting.

Use Kyverno CEL libraries in policy matchConditions

Kyverno 1.16 enables Kyverno CEL libraries in policy matchConditions, not just in rule bodies, so you can target when rules run using richer, context-aware checks. These expressions are evaluated by Kyverno but are not used to build admission webhook matchConditions—webhook routing remains unchanged.

Getting started and backward compatibility

Upgrading to Kyverno 1.16

To upgrade to Kyverno 1.16, you can use Helm: 

helm repo update
helm upgrade --install kyverno kyverno/kyverno -n kyverno --version 3.6.0

Backward compatibility

Kyverno 1.16 remains fully backward compatible with existing ClusterPolicy resources. You can continue running current policies and adopt the new policy types incrementally; once CEL policy types reach GA, the legacy ClusterPolicy API will enter a formal deprecation process following our standard, non‑breaking schedule.

Roadmap

We’re building on 1.16 with a clear, low‑friction path forward. In 1.17, CEL policy types will be available as v1, migration tooling and docs will focus on making upgrades routine. We will continue to expand CEL libraries, samples, and performance optimizations. With SDK and kyverno‑authz maturation to unify admission‑time and runtime enforcement paths. See the release board for the in‑flight work and timelines: Release 1.17.0 Project Board. 

Conclusion

Kyverno 1.16 marks a pivotal step toward a unified, CEL‑powered policy platform: you can adopt the new policy types in beta today, move enforcement closer to teams with namespaced policies, and gain sharper visibility with native Events and detailed latency metrics. Fine‑grained exceptions make rollouts safer without weakening guardrails, while label‑based report suppression and CEL in matchConditions reduce noise and let you target policy execution precisely. 

Looking ahead, the path to v1 and GA is clear, and the ecosystem is expanding with the Kyverno Authz Server and SDK to bring the same policy engine to gateways and services. Upgrade when ready, start with audits where useful, and tell us what you build—your feedback will shape the final polish and the journey to GA.

】

Kyverno 1.16 在策略即 Kubernetes 代码方面取得了重大进展，以新一代基于 CEL 的策略为中心，现已推出测试版，并为 GA 提供了明确的路径。此版本引入了对命名空间 CEL 策略的部分支持，以限制强制执行并最大限度地减少 RBAC，从而与最小特权最佳实践保持一致。通过 CEL 策略和本机事件生成的完整指标，可观察性显着增强，从而实现精确的可见性和更快的故障排除。通过为 CEL 策略定制的细粒度策略例外，安全和治理获得更清晰的控制，并且通过将 HTTP 授权者集成到 ValidatingPolicy 中，验证用例得到扩展。最后，我们将首次推出 Kyverno SDK，为生态系统集成和自定义工具奠定基础。

CEL 政策类型

测试版 CEL 政策

CEL 策略类型作为 v1beta 引入。推广计划提供了一条清晰、不间断的路径：v1 将在 1.17 中提供，GA 的目标是 1.18。此版本包括 v1beta1 的集群范围系列（Validating、Mutating、Generate、Deleting、ImageValidating），并添加了用于验证、删除和图像验证的命名空间变体；命名空间生成和变异将在 1.17 中跟进。 PolicyException和GlobalContextEntry将步调一致，保持版本一致；请参阅此跟踪问题中的推广路线图。

命名空间政策

Kyverno 1.16 引入了命名空间 CEL 策略类型 - NamespacedValidatingPolicy、NamespacedDeletingPolicy 和 NamespacedImageValidatingPolicy - 它们镜像其集群范围内的对应项，但仅适用于策略的命名空间内。这使得团队可以使用最低权限的 RBAC 来实施护栏，并且无需进行集中更改，从而提高了部署过程中的多租户和安全性。为团队拥有的命名空间选择命名空间类型，为全局控制选择集群范围的类型。

可观测性升级

CEL 策略现在具有全面的本地可观察性，可以加快诊断速度：

  • 验证策略执行延迟指标：kyverno_validating_policy_execution_duration_seconds_count、..._sum、..._bucket
    • 测量内容：以 Prometheus 直方图的形式评估每个准入/后台执行的验证策略所花费的时间。 
    • 关键标签：policy_name、policy_background_mode、policy_validation_mode（强制/审核）、resource_kind、resource_namespace、resource_request_operation（创建/更新/删除）、execution_cause（admission_request/background_scan）、结果（PASS/FAIL）。 
  • 变异策略执行延迟：kyverno_mutating_policy_execution_duration_seconds_count、..._sum、..._bucket
    • 测量内容：以 Prometheus 直方图形式执行变异策略（准入/背景）所花费的时间。 
    • 关键标签：policy_name、policy_background_mode、resource_kind、resource_namespace、resource_request_operation、execution_cause、result。 
  • 生成策略执行延迟指标：kyverno_generate_policy_execution_duration_seconds_count、..._sum、..._bucket
    • 衡量的内容：在评估请求或后台扫描期间执行生成策略所花费的时间。 
    • 关键标签：policy_name、policy_background_mode、resource_kind、resource_namespace、resource_request_operation、execution_cause、result。 
  • 图像验证策略执行延迟指标：kyverno_image_validating_policy_execution_duration_seconds_count、..._sum、..._bucket
    • 测量内容：以 Prometheus 直方图形式评估与图像相关的验证策略（例如图像验证）所花费的时间。 
    • 关键标签：policy_name、policy_background_mode、resource_kind、resource_namespace、resource_request_operation、execution_cause、result。 

CEL 策略现在针对通过、违规、错误和具有丰富上下文（策略/规则、资源、用户、模式）的编译/加载问题发出 Kubernetes 事件。这提供了即时、kubectl 可见的反馈，并在部署和故障排除期间更轻松地与准入决策和指标关联。

细粒度的策略例外

基于图像例外

此例外允许 Pod 位于 ci 使用图像，通过 图像 属性，该属性与提供的模式匹配，同时对所有其他图像强制执行 no-latest 规则。它缩小了对特定命名空间和团队的绕过范围，以实现可审核性。

api版本：policies.kyverno.io/v1beta1
种类：PolicyException
元数据：
 名称：允许-ci-最新-图像
 命名空间：ci
规格：
 政策参考：
   - 名称：限制图像标签
     种类：验证策略
 图片：
   -“ghcr.io/kyverno/*：最新”
 匹配条件：
   - 表达式：“has(object.metadata.labels.team) && object.metadata.labels.team == '平台'”

以下 ValidatingPolicy 引用 excepts.allowedImages，它会跳过对白名单图像的验证检查：

api版本：policies.kyverno.io/v1beta1
种类：验证策略
元数据：
名称：限制图像标签
规格：
规则：
  - 名称：经纪人配置
    匹配限制：
      资源规则：
        - apiGroups：[应用程序]
          api版本：[v1]
          操作：[创建、更新]
          资源：[豆荚]
    验证：
     - 消息：“容器不得允许权限升级，除非它们位于允许的映像列表中。”
       表达方式：>
         object.spec.containers.all（容器，
          excepts.allowedImages || 中的字符串（container.image）
          (
            有(container.securityContext) &&
            有（container.securityContext.allowPrivilegeEscalation）&&容器.securityContext.allowPrivilegeEscalation == false
          ）
        ）

基于值的异常

此例外允许通过 CEL 验证使用的 allowedValues 值列表来验证一组受约束的目标，以便团队可以在不削弱整个策略的情况下继续进行。

api版本：policies.kyverno.io/v1beta1
种类：PolicyException
元数据：
 名称：允许调试注释
 命名空间：开发
规格：
 政策参考：
   - 名称：检查安全上下文
     种类：验证策略
 允许值：
   - “调试模式临时”
 匹配条件：
   - 表达式：“object.metadata.name.startsWith('experiments-')”

这是高于允许值的政策杠杆。除非注释值出现在 exceptions.allowedValues 中，否则它会拒绝资源。

api版本：policies.kyverno.io/v1beta1
种类：验证策略
元数据：
 名称：检查安全上下文
规格：
 匹配限制：
   资源规则：
   - apiGroups：[应用程序]
     api版本：[v1]
     操作：[创建、更新]
     资源：[部署]
 变量：
   - 名称：允许的能力
     表达式：“['AUDIT_WRITE'，'CHOWN'，'DAC_OVERRIDE'，'FOWNER'，'FSETID'，'KILL'，'MKNOD'，'NET_BIND_SERVICE'，'SETFCAP'，'SETGID'，'SETPCAP'，'SETUID'，'SYS_CHROOT']”
 验证：
   - 表达式：>-
       object.spec.containers.all（容器，
      容器.?securityContext.?功能.?add.orValue([]).all(功能,
      excepts.allowedValues || 中的功能
      Variables.allowedCapability 中的功能））
     留言：>-
       添加超出允许列表的任何功能（AUDIT_WRITE、CHOWN、DAC_OVERRIDE、FOWNER、
      FSETID、KILL、MKNOD、NET_BIND_SERVICE、SETFCAP、SETGID、SETPCAP、SETUID、SYS_CHROOT）
      是不允许的。

可配置的报告状态

此异常设置reportResult：通过，因此当匹配时，策略报告显示“通过”而不是默认的“跳过”，从而在计划豁免期间改进仪表板和 SLO 信号。

api版本：policies.kyverno.io/v1beta1
种类：PolicyException
元数据：
 名称：排除-跳过-部署-2
 标签：
   pollex.kyverno.io/优先级：“0.2”
规格：
 政策参考：
 - 名称：“有多个例外”
   种类：验证策略
 匹配条件：
   - 名称：“检查名称”
     表达式：“object.metadata.name == '跳过部署'”
 报告结果：通过

Kyverno Authz 服务器

除了丰富准入时间验证之外，Kyverno 现在还将策略决策扩展到您的服务边缘。 Kyverno Authz 服务器应用 Kyverno 策略来授权 Envoy 的请求（通过外部授权过滤器）和作为独立 HTTP 授权服务器的普通 HTTP 服务，根据您在 Kubernetes 中使用的策略引擎相同。这统一了准入、网关和服务之间的策略执行，从而实现一致的护栏和更快的采用，而无需重复逻辑。有关详细信息，请参阅项目页面：kyverno/kyverno-authz。

Kyverno SDK 简介

除了在控制器、CLI 和 CI 中嵌入 CEL 策略评估之外，现在还有一个用于服务边缘授权的配套 SDK。该 SDK 允许您加载 Kyverno 策略、编译它们并评估传入请求，以生成具有结构化结果的允许/拒绝决策 - 为 Envoy 外部授权和普通 HTTP 服务提供支持，而无需重复策略逻辑。它专为网关、sidecar 和应用程序中间件而设计，具有简单的 Go API、可选指标/挂钩以及统一准入时间和运行时执行的路径。请注意，kyverno-authz 仍在积极开发中；从非关键路径开始，并在评估时添加严格的超时。详情请参阅 SDK 包：kyverno SDK。

其他功能和增强功能

基于标签的报告配置

Kyverno 现在支持基于标签的报告抑制。将标签reports.kyverno.io/disabled（任何值，例如“true”）添加到任何策略（ClusterPolicy、CEL 策略类型、ValidatingAdmissionPolicy 或 MutatingAdmissionPolicy），以阻止该策略的所有报告（临时报告和 PolicyReports）。这使得团队可以在不改变执行的情况下消除噪音或暂存政策；删除标签即可恢复报告。

在策略 matchConditions 中使用 Kyverno CEL 库

Kyverno 1.16 在策略 matchConditions 中启用 Kyverno CEL 库，而不仅仅是在规则主体中，因此您可以使用更丰富的上下文感知检查来确定规则运行的时间。这些表达式由 Kyverno 评估，但不用于构建准入 Webhook matchConditions - Webhook 路由保持不变。

入门和向后兼容性

升级到 Kyverno 1.16

要升级到 Kyverno 1.16，您可以使用 Helm：

helm 仓库更新
helm Upgrade --install kyverno kyverno/kyverno -n kyverno --version 3.6.0

向后兼容性

Kyverno 1.16 仍然与现有 ClusterPolicy 资源完全向后兼容。您可以继续运行当前策略并逐步采用新的策略类型；一旦 CEL 策略类型达到 GA，旧版 ClusterPolicy API 将按照我们的标准、不间断时间表进入正式弃用流程。

路线图

我们正在 1.16 的基础上构建一条清晰、低摩擦的前进道路。在 1.17 中，CEL 策略类型将作为 v1 提供，迁移工具和文档将专注于使升级成为常规。我们将继续扩展 CEL 库、示例和性能优化。通过 SDK 和 kyverno-authz 的成熟来统一准入时间和运行时执行路径。有关正在进行的工作和时间表，请参阅发布板：发布 1.17.0 项目板。 

结论

Kyverno 1.16 标志着迈向统一的、由 CEL 支持的策略平台的关键一步：您现在可以采用 Beta 版的新策略类型，使实施更接近具有命名空间策略的团队，并通过本机事件和详细的延迟指标获得更清晰的可见性。细粒度的例外使部署更加安全，同时不会削弱护栏，而 matchConditions 中基于标签的报告抑制和 CEL 可以减少噪音，让您精确定位策略执行。 

展望未来，通往 v1 和 GA 的道路是明确的，生态系统正在通过 Kyverno Authz 服务器和 SDK 进行扩展，为网关和服务带来相同的策略引擎。准备好后进行升级，从有用的审核开始，并告诉我们您构建了什么 - 您的反馈将决定最终的完善和 GA 之旅。

item.title: 【An architectural decision: Containers on bare metal or on virtual machines】架构决策：裸机或虚拟机上的容器
item.description:
【

Building and running modern applications begins with selecting Kubernetes distribution as a baseline. Once a platform team has selected its orchestration layer, one of the next architectural choices involves the deployment architecture where that cluster will run. Containers can be deployed directly on either bare metal servers or virtual machines. This article examines the characteristics, tradeoffs, and community learnings around deploying containers on bare metal compared to virtual machines.

Historically, running workloads in containers on bare metal appealed to organizations that prioritized maximum performance and minimal infrastructure overhead. By bypassing the hypervisor layer, containers could directly access compute and storage resources.

However, advancements in hypervisor technology have significantly improved the performance and efficiency of virtualized environments, making containers on virtual machines (VMs) viable for production workloads  with added operational benefits and flexibility.

As IT requirements have grown in recent years, platform teams now face expanded responsibilities, including enforcing stricter security policies, reducing fault domains for higher application availability, supporting multiple versions of conformant Kubernetes, and meeting tighter service-level agreements (SLAs). These are themes frequently discussed in CNCF TAG Runtime and TAG Security, particularly around multi-tenancy models, workload isolation, and lifecycle management.

These modern demands and technological enhancements have renewed community discussions on where clusters should run and how platform teams can meet SLA, security, and multi-version requirements IT practitioners should consider the following factors when making this decision:

Performance

Historically, bare metal offered a performance edge. Direct hardware access reduced latency and overhead, giving it an advantage in CPU- or GPU-intensive workloads. Recent benchmark studies indicate that the historical performance gap between bare metal and virtualized environments is now negligible. According to MLPerf benchmark tests, containers running on VM platforms can retain up to 99% of bare-metal performance for AI/ML workloads using vGPU. In CNCF projects focused on AI/ML—such as KServe, Kubeflow, and Volcano—platform teams commonly operate across both bare-metal and virtualized environments depending on workload type and scheduling requirements.

Multiple Conformant Kubernetes Versions

Bare metal environments typically support only one Kubernetes version per host. In contrast, containers on VMs allow multiple Kubernetes versions per host, improving host utilization, enabling efficient capacity planning, and supporting more flexible upgrade paths. Operational benefits include the ability to update the Kubernetes version for one application cluster without having to update all application clusters on that same physical cluster.

Security and Isolation

Namespaces are not designed to serve as security boundaries. The core issue in bare metal is that namespaces do not create strong security or isolation boundaries because all containers within a Kubernetes cluster — even across different namespaces — ultimately share the same host kernel. This means a compromise in one container can potentially affect others due to the shared underlying operating system. Stronger isolation is crucial for security (preventing lateral threat movement), compliance (meeting regulations), and multi-tenancy (safely hosting diverse workloads and tenants). VM-based environments provide enhanced isolation for workloads, as each virtual machine operates with its own kernel. Running containers on VMs strengthens workload isolation and reduces cross-tenant blast radius.. This topic is a recurring focus in CNCF TAG Security discussions, especially as organizations adopt multi-tenant platform engineering models.

Resource Guarantees and SLAs

In bare-metal configurations, namespaces enforce “soft” resource limits that can be exceeded when other workloads require those resources. While CPU and memory are assigned to containers, availability is not guaranteed. Containers in VM-based deployments enforce “hard” resource limits at the hypervisor level, with assigned resources reserved and unavailable to other workloads regardless of system demand.  This also addresses “noisy neighbour” problems. This model offers more predictable scheduling and can make it easier for platform teams to meet internal SLAs. 

Choosing the right architecture

Modern hypervisors bring isolation, version flexibility, and near-native performance, which has led many organizations to standardize on VM-based Kubernetes for multi-tenant platforms.Bare metal deployments will have a place for highly specialized or latency-sensitive use cases.

As infrastructure strategies evolve, platform teams are evaluating what combination of virtualized, bare-metal, and GPU-rich environments align best with their operational, performance, and governance requirements.

Leading public cloud providers — host billions of containers globally for thousands of customers — have made a deliberate choice to run their managed Kubernetes services on VM-based infrastructure, not bare metal. This decision reflects a balance between performance parity in most workloads, and the ability to meet strict isolation, security, and SLAs while supporting multiple Kubernetes versions across tenants at scale.

Within the CNCF ecosystem, we see a wide variety of architectures: edge deployments that rely heavily on bare metal, AI/ML platforms using GPU nodes on either model, and enterprise platforms using VMs to simplify lifecycle management. This diversity reflects CNCF’s stance: Kubernetes runs everywhere, and architectural choices depend on workload and governance needs.

As business requirements continue to evolve , the question of which model best fits your workloads and operational goals becomes increasingly relevant for architects and practitioners. It ultimately boils down to what matters most for your organization – absolute performance, or stronger isolation, operational flexibility and predictable SLAs?

】

构建和运行现代应用程序首先选择 Kubernetes 发行版作为基准。一旦平台团队选择了其编排层，下一个架构选择之一涉及该集群将运行的部署架构。容器可以直接部署在裸机服务器或虚拟机上。本文探讨了与虚拟机相比在裸机上部署容器的特征、权衡和社区学习。

从历史上看，在裸机上的容器中运行工作负载吸引了优先考虑最高性能和最小基础设施开销的组织。通过绕过虚拟机管理程序层，容器可以直接访问计算和存储资源。

但是，虚拟机管理程序技术的进步显着提高了虚拟化环境的性能和效率，使虚拟机 (VM) 上的容器能够适用于生产工作负载，并增加了运营优势和灵活性。

随着近年来 IT 需求的增长，平台团队现在面临着更大的责任，包括执行更严格的安全策略、减少故障域以提高应用程序可用性、支持多个版本的一致 Kubernetes 以及满足更严格的服务级别协议 (SLA)。这些是 CNCF TAG 运行时和TAG 安全中经常讨论的主题，特别是围绕多租户模型、工作负载隔离和生命周期管理。

这些现代需求和技术增强重新引发了社区关于集群应在何处运行以及平台团队如何满足 SLA、安全性和多版本要求的讨论。IT 从业者在做出此决定时应考虑以下因素：

性能

从历史上看，裸机提供了性能优势。直接硬件访问减少了延迟和开销，使其在 CPU 或 GPU 密集型工作负载中具有优势。最近的基准研究表明，裸机和虚拟化环境之间的历史性能差距现在可以忽略不计。根据 MLPerf 基准测试，在 VM 平台上运行的容器可以使用 vGPU 为 AI/ML 工作负载保留高达 99% 的裸机性能。在专注于 AI/ML 的 CNCF 项目中（例如 KServe、Kubeflow 和 Volcano），平台团队通常根据工作负载类型和调度在裸机和虚拟化环境中运行要求。

多个一致的 Kubernetes 版本

裸机环境通常每台主机仅支持一个 Kubernetes 版本。相比之下，虚拟机上的容器允许每个主机有多个 Kubernetes 版本，从而提高主机利用率、实现高效的容量规划并支持更灵活的升级路径。运营优势包括能够更新一个应用程序集群的 Kubernetes 版本，而无需更新同一物理集群上的所有应用程序集群。

安全和隔离

命名空间并不是为了充当安全边界而设计的。裸机的核心问题是命名空间无法创建强大的安全性或隔离边界，因为 Kubernetes 集群中的所有容器（甚至跨不同的命名空间）最终共享相同的主机内核。这意味着由于共享底层操作系统，一个容器中的妥协可能会影响其他容器。更强的隔离对于安全性（防止横向威胁移动）、合规性（满足法规）和多租户（安全托管不同的工作负载和租户）至关重要。基于虚拟机的环境为工作负载提供了增强的隔离，因为每个虚拟机都使用自己的内核运行。在虚拟机上运行容器可以增强工作负载隔离并减少跨租户爆炸半径。该主题是 CNCF TAG 安全讨论中反复出现的焦点，特别是在组织采用多租户平台工程模型时。

资源保证和 SLA

在裸机配置中，命名空间会强制实施“软”资源限制，当其他工作负载需要这些资源时，可能会超出这些限制。虽然 CPU 和内存分配给容器，但不能保证可用性。基于虚拟机的部署中的容器在虚拟机管理程序级别强制执行“硬”资源限制，无论系统需求如何，分配的资源都会被保留并且不可用于其他工作负载。  这也解决了“吵闹的邻居”问题。该模型提供了更可预测的调度，可以使平台团队更轻松地满足内部 SLA。 

选择正确的架构

现代虚拟机管理程序带来了隔离性、版本灵活性和接近本机的性能，这使得许多组织在多租户平台的基于虚拟机的 Kubernetes 上实现标准化。裸机部署将为高度专业化或延迟敏感的用例提供一席之地。

随着基础设施战略的发展，平台团队正在评估虚拟化、裸机和 GPU 丰富的环境的组合如何最符合其运营、性能和治理要求。

领先的公共云提供商（在全球为数千名客户托管数十亿个容器）已深思熟虑地选择在基于虚拟机的基础设施上运行其托管 Kubernetes 服务，not 裸机。这一决定反映了大多数工作负载的性能均等性与满足严格隔离、安全性和 SLA 的能力之间的平衡，同时大规模支持跨租户的多个 Kubernetes 版本。

在 CNCF 生态系统中，我们看到了各种各样的架构：严重依赖裸机的边缘部署、在任一模型上使用 GPU 节点的 AI/ML 平台，以及使用虚拟机来简化生命周期管理的企业平台。这种多样性反映了 CNCF 的立场：Kubernetes 无处不在，架构选择取决于工作负载和治理需求。

随着业务需求不断发展，哪种模型最适合您的工作负载和运营目标的问题对于架构师和从业者变得越来越重要。最终归结为什么对您的组织最重要 - 绝对性能，还是更强的隔离、操作灵活性和可预测的 SLA？

item.title: 【What is platform engineering?】什么是平台工程？
item.description:
【

History and evolution of platform engineering

Platform engineering is a discipline focused on building and maintaining software development platforms that provide self-service for developer teams, offering the necessary infrastructure for provisioning an application, for example. The entire flow of development, testing, documentation, deployment, rollback, etc., can happen through developer self-service. It emerged from the need to overcome the limitations of traditional software development, which was often characterized by slow cycles, isolated teams, silos, and complex infrastructures. The main goal of Platform Engineering is to improve the developer experience (DevEx) and optimize software delivery.

In essence, platform engineering seeks to:

  • Provide standardized tools and services: Create a set of tools, services, and workflows that developers can easily use to build, deploy, and manage their applications. These tools can include IDEs, CLIs, project templates, code versioning, CI/CD pipelines, container orchestration tools, configuration management tools, and observability systems.
  • Reduce complexity: Abstract the complexity of the underlying infrastructure and operations, allowing developers to focus on code and business logic. The growing complexity of infrastructure, the cloud computing era with different providers and vendors, multi-cloud adoption, and the proliferation of tools and artifacts in the “everything as code” era led to an increase in developers’ cognitive load. The lack of design patterns also became a problem.
  • Increase productivity: Accelerate the development and deployment cycle, eliminating bottlenecks and repetitive tasks. This is achieved through the automation of tasks such as infrastructure provisioning, application deployment, and configuration management.
  • Improve governance and security: Incorporate security and compliance practices into the platforms from the beginning. platform engineering aims for a more secure and compliant setup by integrating security controls and governance policies.
  • Promote collaboration: Facilitate collaboration between development, operations, security, and product teams. The platform acts as an interface for different teams to work more cohesively, have visibility into solutions, and find what is necessary for the development of their work.

To understand how platform teams operate, it’s essential to view the platform as a product.

Platform as a product

A platform engineering team acts as an “internal provider,” offering a layer of abstraction that allows developers to operate more independently and efficiently. This approach is driven by the “platform as a product” mindset, where the platform is treated as a product with internal developers as its customers. This means the platform team focuses on understanding the needs of its users (primarily application developers) and delivering value to them.

Instead of each development team building and maintaining its own infrastructure and tools, platform engineering centralizes this responsibility, ensuring consistency, scalability, and optimization across the organization.

Comparison with other traditional models (ticket ops vs. self-service)

Traditionally, developers depended on operations teams to provision infrastructure and perform operational tasks. This model, often called “ticket ops,” generated significant delays, bottlenecks, and an unsatisfactory developer experience, as they were “blocked” waiting for ticket resolution; creating a mere user on a server could take a long time, delaying development. This approach resulted not only in delays but also in even more fragmented knowledge, which could become a bottleneck, especially with undocumented solutions.

Contrary to what some may think, platform engineering is a natural evolution of DevOps and transforms this scenario by focusing on creating self-service solutions. It allows developers to perform common tasks on their own, such as provisioning resources, deploying applications, and managing configurations, without depending on operations teams. This is done through:

  • Self-service interfaces: APIs, automation tools, and web portals that simplify access to and interaction with the infrastructure. An internal developer portal (IDP) is a centralized environment where developers can create, discover, consume, explore, test APIs, and get support.
  • Golden paths and paved roads: Defines and automates the preferred and approved approaches for software development and deployment. This reduces cognitive load, as developers do not need to learn every detail of each tool, and it ensures compliance and security. The implementation of a “check/scorecard” system in an existing IDP, for example, significantly impacted developer engagement by providing “applicable and concrete actions” for improvement.
  • Platform orchestrators: Tools that act as a central link, managing the platform’s lifecycle and orchestrating the infrastructure and application configurations, potentially even replacing categories of tools like Terraform and Ansible.

The benefits of platform engineering

The adoption of platform engineering aims to solve several common challenges in software development and, consequently, offer a series of tangible benefits for organizations:

Problems it seeks to solve

  • High cognitive load for developers: The need for developers to understand and manage the complexities of infrastructure, Kubernetes, CI/CD pipelines, and security. platform engineering reduces this cognitive load by abstracting infrastructure and automating tasks.
  • Lack of standardization and consistency: Different teams using inconsistent tools and processes, leading to errors and inefficiencies. PE promotes standardization and consistency in environments and workflows.
  • Slow development cycles and operational bottlenecks: Manual processes, dependencies on operations teams, and difficulties in continuous integration and delivery. The “ticket ops” model exemplifies this slowness.
  • Fragmented security and compliance: Difficulty in ensuring that all applications and infrastructures follow security policies and regulations.
  • High cost of development and maintenance: Redundancy of efforts and time spent on repetitive tasks.

Benefits:

  • Increased developer productivity and efficiency (DevEx): By automating repetitive tasks and providing ready-to-use components, PE accelerates development and deployment, freeing up developers to focus on innovation and writing code. This improves the developer experience by providing a friendly, self-service environment.
  • Reduced time-to-market: Accelerates product and feature release cycles, allowing companies to respond quickly to market demands.
  • Improved security and compliance: Integrating security controls and governance policies from the platform’s design phase. This reduces risks and vulnerabilities and makes it easier to implement uniform security policies.
  • Cost optimization: Automation and standardization of processes lead to reduced operational expenses and more efficient use of IT resources.
  • Greater agility and scalability: Allows organizations to adapt more quickly to changes and expand their operations efficiently. PE provides the necessary tools to handle demand growth without compromising performance or security.
  • Attraction and retention of talent: A modern and efficient work environment, with less friction and more autonomy, is more attractive to top engineering professionals.

Competitive differentiation: Enables the development of unique and innovative solutions, making the company stand out in the market.

】

平台工程的历史和演变

平台工程是一门专注于构建和维护软件开发平台的学科，这些平台为开发团队提供自助服务，例如为配置应用程序提供必要的基础设施。开发、测试、文档、部署、回滚等整个流程都可以通过开发人员自助服务进行。它的出现是为了克服传统软件开发的局限性，传统软件开发的特点通常是周期慢、团队孤立、孤岛和复杂的基础设施。平台工程的主要目标是改善开发人员体验 (DevEx) 并优化软件交付。

本质上，平台工程旨在：

  • 提供标准化工具和服务：创建一组工具、服务和工作流程，开发人员可以轻松使用它们来构建、部署和管理其应用程序。这些工具可以包括 IDE、CLI、项目模板、代码版本控制、CI/CD 管道、容器编排工具、配置管理工具和可观察性系统。
  • 降低复杂性：抽象底层基础设施和操作的复杂性，使开发人员能够专注于代码和业务逻辑。基础设施的日益复杂性、不同提供商和供应商的云计算时代、多云采用以及“一切皆代码”时代工具和工件的激增导致了开发人员认知负荷的增加。缺乏设计模式也成为一个问题。
  • 提高工作效率：加快开发和部署周期，消除瓶颈和重复性任务。这是通过基础设施配置、应用程序部署和配置管理等任务的自动化来实现的。
  • 改善治理和安全：从一开始就将安全和合规实践纳入平台。平台工程旨在通过集成安全控制和治理策略来实现更安全、更合规的设置。
  • 促进协作：促进开发、运营、安全和产品团队之间的协作。该平台充当不同团队的界面，使他们能够更加团结地工作，了解解决方案，并找到工作发展所需的内容。

要了解平台团队如何运作，必须将平台视为产品。

平台即产品

平台工程团队充当“内部提供商”，提供抽象层，使开发人员能够更独立、更高效地运营。这种方法是由“平台即产品”思维驱动的，其中 platform 被视为一种产品，内部开发人员被视为其客户。这意味着平台团队专注于了解用户（主要是应用程序开发人员）的需求并为他们提供价值。

平台工程不是每个开发团队都构建和维护自己的基础架构和工具，而是集中了这一职责，确保整个组织的一致性、可扩展性和优化。

与其他传统模式的比较（票务操作与自助服务）

传统上，开发人员依靠运营团队来配置基础设施并执行运营任务。这种模型通常被称为“票务操作”，会产生严重的延迟、瓶颈和令人不满意的开发人员体验，因为他们在等待票证解决时被“阻塞”；在服务器上创建一个用户可能需要很长时间，从而延迟开发。这种方法不仅导致延迟，而且导致知识更加碎片化，这可能成为瓶颈，特别是对于未记录的解决方案。

与某些人的想法相反，平台工程是 DevOps 的自然演变，并通过专注于创建自助服务解决方案来改变这种情况。它允许开发人员自行执行常见任务，例如配置资源、部署应用程序和管理配置，而无需依赖运营团队。这是通过以下方式完成的：

  • 自助服务界面：API、自动化工具和门户网站，可简化对基础设施的访问和交互。内部开发人员门户 (IDP) 是一个集中式环境，开发人员可以在其中创建、发现、使用、探索、测试 API 并获取支持。
  • 黄金路径和铺好的道路：定义并自动化首选和批准的软件开发和部署方法。这减少了认知负担，因为开发人员不需要了解每个工具的每个细节，并且确保了合规性和安全性。例如，在现有 IDP 中实施“检查/记分卡”系统，通过提供“适用且具体的改进行动”，极大地影响了开发人员的参与度。
  • 平台编排器：充当中心链接的工具，管理平台的生命周期并编排基础架构和应用程序配置，甚至有可能取代 Terraform 和 Ansible 等工具类别。

平台工程的好处

采用平台工程旨在解决软件开发中的几个常见挑战，从而为组织提供一系列切实的好处：

它寻求解决的问题

  • 开发人员的高认知负荷： 开发人员需要了解和管理基础设施、Kubernetes、CI/CD 管道和安全性的复杂性。平台工程通过抽象基础设施和自动化任务来减少这种认知负担。
  • 缺乏标准化和一致性：不同的团队使用不一致的工具和流程，导致错误和效率低下。 PE 促进环境和工作流程的标准化和一致性。
  • 开发周期缓慢和运营瓶颈：手动流程、对运营团队的依赖以及持续集成和交付方面的困难。 “ticket ops”模型就是这种缓慢的例证。
  • 安全性和合规性分散：难以确保所有应用程序和基础设施都遵循安全政策和法规。
  • 开发和维护成本高昂：在重复性任务上花费大量精力和时间。

好处：

  • 提高开发人员生产力和效率 (DevEx)：通过自动执行重复性任务并提供即用型组件，PE 可以加速开发和部署，使开发人员能够专注于创新和编写代码。这通过提供友好的自助服务环境改善了开发者体验。
  • 缩短上市时间：加快产品和功能发布周期，使公司能够快速响应市场需求。
  • 提高安全性和合规性：从平台设计阶段就集成安全控制和治理策略。这可以降低风险和漏洞，并更轻松地实施统一的安全策略。
  • 成本优化：流程自动化和标准化可降低运营费用并更有效地利用 IT 资源。
  • 更高的敏捷性和可扩展性：使组织能够更快地适应变化并高效地扩展运营。 PE 提供了必要的工具来应对需求增长，而不会影响性能或安全性。
  • 吸引和留住人才：现代化、高效的工作环境、更少的摩擦和更多的自主权，对顶尖工程专业人士更具吸引力。

差异化竞争：能够开发独特且创新的解决方案，使公司在市场中脱颖而出。

item.title: 【Kgateway v2.1 is released!】Kgateway v2.1 发布了！
item.description:
【

Kgateway is an open source implementation of the Kubernetes Gateway API that unifies ingress, API gateway, service mesh, and AI gateway capabilities in a singular modular control plane. Built for performance and flexibility, it secures and manages traffic across legacy, cloud native, and AI-driven workloads in any environment.

We’re excited to announce the release of kgateway v2.1., a release packed with exciting new features and improvements. Here are a few select updates the kgateway team would like to highlight!

🌟 What’s new in kgateway 2.1?

Agentgateway integration

This release marks a major milestone — it’s the first version to integrate the open source project agentgateway! Agentgateway is a highly available, highly scalable data plane that provides AI connectivity for LLMs, MCP tools, AI agents, and inference workloads. As part of this evolution, we’re beginning the deprecation of the Envoy-based AI Gateway and the Envoy-based Inference Extension, since all related functionality is now implemented natively through agentgateway. You can still continue to use Envoy-based Gateways for API Gateway use cases. 

For this release, agentgateway support is in beta. If you’re trying out the agentgateway GatewayClass, we recommend following the beta release feed to stay up to date with improvements, bug fixes, and breaking changes as the implementation is refined.

To get started with agentgateway, you simply install kgateway with the following Helm values: 

agentgateway:
  enabled: true

Then you create a Gateway with the agentgateway GatewayClass as shown here: 

kubectl apply -f- <<EOF
kind: Gateway
apiVersion: gateway.networking.k8s.io/v1
metadata:
  name: agentgateway
  namespace: kgateway-system
  labels:
    app: agentgateway
spec:
  gatewayClassName: agentgateway
  listeners:
  - protocol: HTTP
    port: 8080
    name: http
    allowedRoutes:
      namespaces:
        from: All
EOF

You are now ready to try out agentgateway. Check out the agentgateway guides to learn how to route traffic to an LLM provider, MCP tool server, or AI agent. 

Check out the accompanying examples demonstrating how agentgateway connects to MCP servers and A2A agents:

K8s GW API 1.3.0 and Inference Extension 1.0.0

Kgateway is now fully conformant with the Kubernetes Gateway API version 1.3.0 and Inference Extension version 1.0.0. For details, check out the conformance test reports: 

  • Kubernetes Gateway API
  • Inference Extension

Global policy attachment

By default, you must attach policies to resources that are in the same namespace. Now, you can enable a feature to create a global namespace for policies. These global policies can attach to resources in any namespace in your cluster through label selectors. For more information, see the Global policy attachment docs.

Deep merging for extauth and extproc policies 

You can now apply deep merging for extAuth and extProc policies. In addition, you can use the kgateway.dev/policy-weight annotation to determine the priority in which multiple extAuth and extProc policies are merged. For more information, see Policy priority during merging. 

Additional proxy pod template customization 

kgateway now has more options to customize the gateway proxies’ default pod template, including configuration for nodeSelectors, affinity, tolerations, topologySpreadConstraints, and externalTrafficPolicy.

For more information, see Customize the gateway. To find all the values that you can change, see the PodTemplate reference in the GatewayParameters API.

Horizontal Pod Autoscaling

You can bring your own Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) plug-in to kgateway. This way, you can automatically scale kgateway control and data plane pods up and down based on thresholds like CPU or memory consumption. See Horizontal Pod Autoscaling (HPA) for more information.

Dynamic Forward Proxy 

You can now configure the gateway proxy to use a Dynamic Forward Proxy (DFP) filter. This filter allows the proxy to act as a generic HTTP(S) forward proxy without the need to preconfigure all possible upstream hosts. Instead, the DFP dynamically resolves the upstream host at request time by using DNS. Check out Dynamic Forward Proxy (DFP) for more information.

Session Affinity

You can now configure different types of session affinity for your Envoy-based gateway proxies:

  • Change the default loadbalancing algorithm: By default, incoming requests are forwarded to the instance with the least requests. You can change this behavior and instead use a round robin or random algorithm to forward the request to a backend service.
  • Consistent hashing: Set up soft session affinity between a client and a backend service by using consistent hashing algorithms. 
  • Session persistence: Set up “strong” session affinity or sticky sessions to ensure that traffic from a client is always routed to the same backend instance for the duration of a session.

Enhanced retries and timeout capabilities

Retries and timeout capabilities have been enhanced for your Envoy-based gateway proxies. Check out the following guides for more information: 

  • Request retries
  • Request timeouts
  • Per-try timeouts
  • Idle timeouts
  • Idle stream timeouts

Passive health checks with outlier detection

You can now configure passive health checks and remove unhealthy hosts from the load balancing pool with an outlier detection policy. An outlier detection policy sets up several conditions, such as retries and ejection percentages, that kgateway uses to determine if a service is unhealthy. When an unhealthy service is detected, the outlier detection policy defines how the service is removed from the pool of healthy destinations to send traffic to. For more information, see Outlier detection.

New kgateway operations dashboard 

When you install the OTel stack, you can now leverage the new kgateway operations dashboard for Grafana. This dashboard shows important metrics at a glance, such as the translation and reconciliation time, total number of operations, the number of resources in your cluster, and latency.

Check out this demo of some of kgateway’s new features in global policy attachment, HPA, monitoring, and observability:

🗑️ Deprecated or removed features

AI Gateway and Inference Extension support for Envoy-based gateway proxies is deprecated and is planned to be removed in version 2.2. If you want to use AI capabilities, use an agentgateway proxy instead. To learn more about why we think that agentgateway is better suited as a gateway for agentic AI and MCP workloads, check out this blog. 

Release notes

Check out the full details of the kgateway v2.1 release in our release notes.

Availability

Ready to get started? Download the latest release on GitHub. Then, check out our getting started guide to install kgateway. 

Thanks to our contributors!

The kgateway v2.1 release includes 602 contributions from 42 contributors. Check out the project dev stats for the v2.1 release cycle. We would like to extend our sincere gratitude to all the contributors!

This release also marks kgateway’s first participation in the LFX Mentorship Program! Our mentees have contributed across a range of initiatives across the project, including automated scale tests for kgateway, improving ecosystem integrations documentation, OpenTelemetry observability for AI Extensions, and observability improvements for agentgateway. Aryan Parashar, one of our current Term 3 mentees, also co-authored this blog!

Get Involved

The simplest way to get involved with kgateway is by joining our Slack and community meetings.

Thank you for your continued feedback and support!

】

我们很高兴地宣布发布 kgateway v2.1.，该版本包含令人兴奋的新功能和改进。以下是 kgateway 团队想要强调的一些精选更新！

代理网关集成

此版本标志着一个重要的里程碑 - 它是第一个集成开源项目 agentgateway 的版本！ Agentgateway 是一个高度可用、高度可扩展的数据平面，可为 LLM、MCP 工具、AI 代理和推理工作负载提供 AI 连接。作为这一演变的一部分，我们开始弃用基于 Envoy 的 AI 网关和基于 Envoy 的推理扩展，因为所有相关功能现在都是通过 Agentgateway 本地实现的。您仍然可以继续将基于 Envoy 的网关用于 API 网关用例。 

在此版本中，代理网关支持处于测试版阶段。如果您正在尝试 agentgateway GatewayClass，我们建议您关注 Beta 版本源，以便在实施完善时及时了解改进、错误修复和重大更改。

要开始使用 agentgateway，您只需使用以下 Helm 值安装 kgateway：

  启用：true





然后，您使用 agentgateway GatewayClass 创建一个网关，如下所示：

种类：网关
api版本：gateway.networking.k8s.io/v1

  命名空间：kgateway-system
  标签：
    应用：代理网关
规格：
  gatewayClassName：代理网关
  听众：
  - 协议：HTTP
    端口：8080
    名称：http
    允许的路由：
      命名空间：
        来自：全部
EOF





您现在已准备好尝试代理网关。查看 agentgateway 指南，了解如何将流量路由到 LLM 提供商、MCP 工具服务器或 AI 代理。

item.title: 【Top 5 hard-earned lessons from the experts on managing Kubernetes】管理 Kubernetes 专家总结的 5 个来之不易的经验教训
item.description:
【

Kubernetes has transformed how modern organizations deploy and operate scalable infrastructure, and the hype around automated cloud native orchestration has made its adoption nearly ubiquitous over the past 10+ years. Yet behind the scenes, most teams embarking on their Kubernetes journey quickly encounter operational complexity, configuration challenges, and costly maintenance that few vendors highlight.

Drawing from years of real-world experience architecting, building, and maintaining Kubernetes, we recently hosted a webinar sharing five hard-earned lessons to help organizations get started using the container orchestration tool. In this post, we’ve paired each lesson with useful resources and examples of how to navigate managing Kubernetes at scale, whether supporting your own teams, deploying across multiple clusters, or evaluating managed Kubernetes offerings.

1. Operational overhead catches teams off guard

The Kubernetes community knows that spinning up a cluster is straightforward, especially if you use a managed provider such as AKS, EKS, or GKE. But in reality, running a production environment means managing all the hidden add-ons: DNS controllers, networking, storage, monitoring, logging, secrets, security, and more. Supporting internal users (dev teams, ops, and data scientists) adds significant overhead for any company running Kubernetes.

Internal Slack channels are often flooded with requests, driving the rise of platform engineering and developer self-service solutions to reduce overhead. Of course, someone on the backend needs to have created all the capabilities to make it easy for developers to deploy their applications, and every layer of abstraction affects support and troubleshooting. As more complexity is hidden from developers, it becomes harder for them to debug issues independently. Successful teams strike a careful balance between usability and transparency.

2. Hidden corners: Security issues put clusters at risk

Managed platforms and cloud vendors promise quick cluster creation, which is true — it’s quick and easy to spin up a cluster. But these clusters are rarely ready for real workloads. They lack hardened security, proper resource requests and limits, key integrations, and monitoring essentials.

Production readiness means planning server access, role-based access control (RBAC), network policy, add-ons, CI/CD integration, and disaster recovery before deploying a single business application. Deploying a secure, production-ready Kubernetes environment requires careful attention to configuration details and resource specifications. Getting these details right protects both your system and your client data.

Default settings

Default settings are almost never secure. In fact, you’re going to need to think about what kind of cluster access you want to give — and which people you want to give access to. You’ll have to create RBAC permissions, RBAC roles, and cluster roles. Specs may look simple, but clusters contain multiple objects with confusing names. Understanding them is required for true security. Keep in mind: Kubernetes lacks built-in identity and access management (IAM), so you must carefully manage access permissions and endpoint exposure.

All this complexity often leads to overprovisioned built-in cluster roles, giving users far more permissions than necessary. These days, cloud providers are making some of this a lot easier by integrating IAM and RBAC tools, like AWS IAM Roles for Service Accounts (IRSA), into their authentication mechanisms.

Network policy and namespace isolation

While Kubernetes namespaces offer logical isolation, by default there is no network separation. True isolation requires explicit network policies and a compatible CNI, which means planning, testing, and ongoing tuning.

Containers and the images you run in them

Despite a lot of news about software supply chain issues, many organisations still don’t scan container images before using them. Pulling container images from public registries is convenient, but it also introduces potential risks. Images are usually built of many layers of other images, and they can contain vulnerabilities.

Always scan, validate, and track the provenance of every image — understand where images come from, how they’re built, and who maintains them. Establish a plan to mitigate any vulnerabilities you discover during scanning. Some vendors offer patched, secure images by subscription, reducing your team’s burden when it comes to CVE mitigation and vulnerability management.

3. Scaling challenges that stall growth and agility

Kubernetes excels at scaling. You no longer need to manually provision new servers or manage spike-time connections. Kubernetes handles that complexity automatically.

The initial setup is deceptively simple: dropping in a Cluster Autoscaler and a Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) and telling them to go. But this simplicity hides two major considerations that, if ignored, lead to problems: runaway costs and inconsistent performance.

The cost of node scaling

Node autoscalers are essential for elasticity but can create serious financial risk if not properly bound. Always set upper limits to prevent runaway cloud bills and oversized, expensive nodes. Also, without explicit guidance on instance families, tools like Karpenter can select expensive, oversized nodes. This common mistake can lead to teams celebrating high availability without realizing they are also incurring massive costs.

The right metrics for pod scaling

The HPA is easy to deploy, but choosing the right metric is difficult. The simplest route is scaling based on generic metrics like CPU and memory. However, this is rarely accurate, as most modern applications are not truly bottlenecked by these resources. Effective, cost-efficient scaling requires moving to custom metrics, such as requests per second or queue size. This is more complex to implement, but it provides a clear, accurate reflection of application load, preventing over-scaling (and over-paying) while ensuring consistent user performance.

Ultimately, these scaling components are not isolated. They form a complex mesh that ties your Pod’s resource settings to the Cluster Autoscaler’s decisions. The biggest lesson here is realizing that Kubernetes makes distributed computing accessible, but you need to configure these automated systems carefully to make them work together effectively.

4. Talent acquisition: High talent costs and skill gaps in Kubernetes expertise

The foundational lesson in managing Kubernetes is that people are your most critical resource. Kubernetes is a complex piece of infrastructure that has only been widely adopted for a handful of years. This brief lifespan, combined with the technology’s depth, means:

  • Talent is scarce: The percentage of technologists who have genuinely deep, real-world experience running Kubernetes in a production environment is small.
  • Costs are high: Due to this scarcity, professionals with proven Kubernetes experience command high salaries, making it a significant budgetary consideration before you commit to the platform.

It’s also important to understand the difference between knowing Kubernetes and operating it at scale. While running a Kubernetes cluster on a local machine or as a hobby project is great for learning, it does not translate to the production demands of a cloud platform. Real-world experience involves managing upgrades, ensuring stability, controlling costs, and dealing with complex integrations.

Without genuine K8s expertise, organizations risk stagnation. We’ve seen environments where the entire cluster was deployed via rudimentary batch scripts written by a single developer. When that person left, no one felt comfortable upgrading the system, leaving the company stuck on an outdated version for years. Does your team have the requisite experience to operate and maintain this platform, or have you budgeted for the resources necessary to manage it for you?

5. Technical debt piling up faster than teams can manage

While moving to the cloud and Kubernetes eliminates the need to upgrade physical servers or operating systems, it introduces a new form of technical debt centered on the evolving ecosystem.

This debt manifests in two primary ways.

Ongoing upgrades

You must constantly manage updates to maintain security and stability:

  • Kubernetes core: Even with a reduced release cadence (now three times a year), keeping the main cluster components current (N+1) is mandatory. Major version changes can introduce breaking changes, for example, migrating from Ingress to the Gateway API.
  • Essential add-ons: The cluster is useless without foundational components like CoreDNS and your CNI. These add-ons operate on independent release schedules, requiring constant monitoring for updates and breaking changes.

This work takes significant, dedicated time for research, testing, and deployment. When teams are occupied with developer support and troubleshooting, upgrade work is frequently delayed. Tech debt piles up until a CVE forces a massive, risky, and time-consuming jump across several versions at once.

A shifting tooling landscape

Beyond upgrading existing tools, the Kubernetes ecosystem itself is always evolving, introducing better patterns that render older approaches obsolete or deprecated.

  • Relying on tools that were standard five years ago may leave you using inefficient or, worse, unsupported components. Ignoring new projects and standards risks falling behind.
  • The best practices for critical functions change over time. For example, the shift from encrypting secrets in Git (for example, with tools like SOPS) to using External Secrets Operators that pull secrets directly from vaults.
  • The slow but mandatory migration from the traditional Ingress resource to the more powerful Gateway API.

If your team isn’t dedicating time to tracking new CNCF projects and assessing whether new tools solve old problems, you risk becoming locked into a deprecated tool that stops receiving important security patches, forcing a chaotic, emergency migration. Staying secure and reliable requires constant awareness of the ecosystem

Bonus lesson: Not every workload belongs on Kubernetes

Teams often adopt Kubernetes before asking if their business needs justify its complexity. But some workloads benefit more from simple hosting or a dedicated VM. There’s no reason to run a personal blog, simple data pipeline, or one-off batch job on Kubernetes just because it’s trendy.

Start with business needs and use Kubernetes where it solves real problems. Avoid the temptation to deploy “service mesh everywhere” or use “Kubernetes by default.” Focus on outcomes, simplicity, and efficiency.

Bonus lesson: Policy enforcement

When working with Kubernetes, the beauty of its declarative API is the ability to enforce all security and best practice rules as structured policy.

There are a number of open source policy engines to manage this, including:

  • Open Policy Agent (OPA) (via Gatekeeper): A general-purpose policy engine that uses the powerful Rego language.
  • Kyverno: A Kubernetes-native engine that lets you write policies directly in YAML (no new language needed).
  • Polaris: A policy engine that focuses on auditing and automatically enforcing best-practice policies for security, efficiency, and reliability.

The most critical takeaway is to enable these policy engines from the beginning. If you start deploying apps on a bare-bones cluster and then implement a policy engine later, you’ll suddenly block insecure deployments. This will lead to frustration and resistance because the devs’ established (but insecure) workloads will no longer be allowed to run.

Building reliable, secure, and efficient Kubernetes

Kubernetes is a game-changer for infrastructure, but sustainable adoption requires practical knowledge, ongoing investment, and a willingness to seek help when needed. By learning from those who’ve managed hundreds of clusters at scale, and embracing community and expert support, organizations can build robust, secure, and cost-effective Kubernetes environments that empower innovation rather than inhibit it.

To truly succeed with Kubernetes, whether self-managed or outsourced, organizations should:

  • Invest time upfront in security, policy, and user permissions management.
  • Leverage automated tooling and proactive alerting for upgrades and add-on maintenance
  • Validate business needs before deploying new clusters or expanding Kubernetes usage
  • Seek community support through resources, Slack groups, and open source tool documentation
  • Consider managed solutions if talent, time, or operational risk are concerns

If your team is planning a new Kubernetes deployment or struggling with production stability, these lessons are a foundation for long-term success.

If you’re ready to eliminate operational headaches and focus on value, organizations may also explore managed Kubernetes offerings from the ecosystem when internal resources are limited.

】

Kubernetes 改变了现代组织部署和运营可扩展基础设施的方式，而围绕自动化云原生编排的炒作使其在过去 10 多年里几乎无处不在。然而，在幕后，大多数踏上 Kubernetes 之旅的团队很快就会遇到运营复杂性、配置挑战和昂贵的维护，而很少有供应商强调这一点。

根据多年设计、构建和维护 Kubernetes 的实际经验，我们最近举办了一次网络研讨会，分享了五个来之不易的经验教训，以帮助组织开始使用容器编排工具。在这篇文章中，我们为每节课程配备了有用的资源和示例，说明如何大规模管理 Kubernetes，无论是支持您自己的团队、跨多个集群部署还是评估托管 Kubernetes 产品。

1. 运营开销让团队措手不及

Kubernetes 社区知道启动集群非常简单，特别是当您使用 AKS、EKS 或 GKE 等托管提供商时。但实际上，运行生产环境意味着管理所有隐藏的附加组件：DNS 控制器、网络、存储、监控、日志记录、机密、安全性等等。支持内部用户（开发团队、运营人员和数据科学家）会给任何运行 Kubernetes 的公司带来巨大的开销。

内部 Slack 渠道经常充斥着请求，推动了平台工程和开发人员自助服务解决方案的兴起，以减少开销。当然，后端人员需要创建所有功能，以便开发人员轻松部署应用程序，并且每一层抽象都会影响支持和故障排除。由于开发人员隐藏了更多的复杂性，他们独立调试问题变得更加困难。成功的团队在可用性和透明度之间取得了谨慎的平衡。

2.隐藏的角落：安全问题使集群面临风险

托管平台和云供应商承诺快速创建集群，这是事实——启动集群既快速又简单。但这些集群很少为真正的工作负载做好准备。它们缺乏强化的安全性、适当的资源请求和限制、关键集成和监控要素。

生产准备就绪意味着在部署单个业务应用程序之前规划服务器访问、基于角色的访问控制 (RBAC)、网络策略、附加组件、CI/CD 集成和灾难恢复。部署安全、生产就绪的 Kubernetes 环境需要仔细注意配置细节和资源规范。正确获取这些详细信息可以保护您的系统和客户数据。

默认设置

默认设置几乎永远不会被设置治愈。事实上，您需要考虑您想要授予哪种集群访问权限，以及您想要授予哪些人访问权限。您必须创建 RBAC 权限、RBAC 角色和集群角色。规格可能看起来很简单，但集群包含多个名称令人困惑的对象。了解它们是真正的安全所必需的。请记住：Kubernetes 缺乏内置的身份和访问管理 (IAM)，因此您必须仔细管理访问权限和端点暴露。

所有这些复杂性通常会导致过度配置内置集群角色，从而为用户提供远远超出必要的权限。如今，云提供商通过将 IAM 和 RBAC 工具（例如 AWS IAM 服务帐户角色 (IRSA)）集成到其身份验证机制中，使这一切变得更加容易。

网络策略和命名空间隔离

虽然 Kubernetes 命名空间提供逻辑隔离，但默认情况下没有网络隔离。真正的隔离需要明确的网络策略和兼容的 CNI，这意味着规划、测试和持续调整。

容器以及在其中运行的镜像

尽管有很多关于软件供应链问题的新闻，但许多组织在使用容器映像之前仍然不会扫描它们。从公共注册表中提取容器镜像很方便，但也带来了潜在的风险。图像通常由许多其他图像层构建，并且它们可能包含漏洞。

始终扫描、验证和跟踪每个图像的出处 - 了解图像的来源、它们的构建方式以及由谁维护它们。制定计划来缓解扫描过程中发现的任何漏洞。一些供应商通过订阅提供经过修补的安全映像，从而减轻您的团队在 CVE 缓解和漏洞管理方面的负担。

3.阻碍增长和敏捷性的扩展挑战

Kubernetes 擅长扩展。您不再需要手动配置新服务器或管理峰值时间连接。 Kubernetes 自动处理这种复杂性。

初始设置看似简单：放入 Cluster Autoscaler 和 Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) 并告诉它们运行。但这种简单性隐藏了两个主要考虑因素，如果忽视，就会导致问题：成本失控和性能不一致。

节点扩展的成本

节点自动缩放器对于弹性至关重要，但如果绑定不当，可能会造成严重的财务风险。始终设置上限，以防止云账单失控和节点过大、昂贵。此外，如果没有对实例系列的明确指导，Karpenter 等工具可能会选择昂贵的超大节点。这个常见的错误可能会导致团队庆祝高可用性，但没有意识到他们也付出了巨大的成本。

Pod 扩展的正确指标

HPA 易于部署，但选择正确的指标却很困难。最简单的途径是基于 CPU 和内存等通用指标进行扩展。然而，这很少准确，因为大多数现代应用程序并没有真正受到这些资源的瓶颈。有效、经济高效的扩展需要转向自定义指标，例如每秒请求数或队列大小。这实现起来比较复杂，但它可以清晰、准确地反映应用程序负载，防止过度扩展（和过度付费），同时确保一致的用户性能。

最终，这些扩展组件并不是孤立的。它们形成了一个复杂的网格，将 Pod 的资源设置与 Cluster Autoscaler 的决策联系起来。这里最大的教训是认识到 Kubernetes 使分布式计算变得易于访问，但您需要仔细配置这些自动化系统以使它们有效地协同工作。

4.人才获取：高人才成本和 Kubernetes 专业知识的技能差距

管理 Kubernetes 的基本教训是，人员是最重要的资源。 Kubernetes 是一个复杂的基础设施，仅仅几年时间就被广泛采用。这种短暂的生命周期与技术的深度相结合意味着：

  • 人才稀缺：真正拥有在生产环境中运行 Kubernetes 的深厚实际经验的技术人员所占比例很小。
  • 成本高昂：由于这种稀缺性，拥有成熟 Kubernetes 经验的专业人员的薪水很高，因此在您投入该平台之前，这是一个重要的预算考虑因素。

了解了解 Kubernetes 和大规模运营它之间的区别也很重要。虽然在本地计算机上运行 Kubernetes 集群或作为业余爱好项目非常适合学习，但它并不能转化为云平台的生产需求。实际经验包括管理升级、确保稳定性、控制成本以及处理复杂的集成。

如果没有真正的 K8s 专业知识，组织就会面临停滞的风险。我们见过这样的环境：整个集群是通过单个开发人员编写的基本批处理脚本来部署的。当那个人离开后，没有人愿意升级系统，导致公司多年来一直使用过时的版本。您的团队是否具备运营和维护该平台所需的经验，或者您是否已为管理该平台所需的资源制定了预算？

5。技术债务堆积的速度超出了团队的管理速度

在迁移到云和 Kubernetes el 时消除了升级物理服务器或操作系统的需要，它引入了一种以不断发展的生态系统为中心的新形式的技术债务。

这种债务主要表现在两个方面。

持续升级

您必须不断管理更新以维护安全性和稳定性：

  • Kubernetes 核心：即使发布频率降低（现在每年三次），保持主要集群组件最新 (N+1) 也是强制性的。主要版本更改可能会带来重大更改，例如从 Ingress 迁移到 Gateway API。
  • 基本附加组件：如果没有 CoreDNS 和 CNI 等基础组件，集群就毫无用处。这些附加组件按照独立的发布计划运行，需要持续监控更新和重大更改。

这项工作需要大量的专门时间来进行研究、测试和部署。当团队忙于开发人员支持和故障排除时，升级工作经常会被延迟。技术债务不断累积，直到 CVE 迫使多个版本同时进行大规模、危险且耗时的跳跃。

不断变化的工具格局

除了升级现有工具之外，Kubernetes 生态系统本身也在不断发展，引入更好的模式，使旧方法过时或被弃用。

  • 依赖五年前的标准工具可能会让您使用低效的组件，或者更糟糕的是，使用不受支持的组件。忽视新项目和标准可能会导致落后。
  • 关键功能的最佳实践会随着时间的推移而变化。例如，从在 Git 中加密机密（例如使用 SOPS 等工具）转变为使用直接从保管库提取机密的外部机密操作员。
  • 从传统 Ingress 资源缓慢但强制迁移到更强大的 Gateway API。

如果您的团队没有花时间跟踪新的 CNCF 项目并评估新工具是否可以解决老问题，那么您可能会被锁定在已弃用的工具中，该工具将停止接收重要的安全补丁，从而迫使您进行混乱的紧急迁移。保持安全可靠需要不断了解生态系统

额外教训：并非所有工作负载都适合 Kubernetes

团队通常会在询问其业务需求是否证明其复杂性合理之前就采用 Kubernetes。但某些工作负载从简单托管或专用虚拟机中获益更多。没有理由仅仅因为流行就在 Kubernetes 上运行个人博客、简单的数据管道或一次性批处理作业。

从业务开始满足需求并使用 Kubernetes 来解决实际问题。避免部署“无处不在的服务网格”或“默认使用 Kubernetes”的诱惑。注重结果、简单性和效率。

额外课程：政策执行

在使用 Kubernetes 时，其声明式 API 的优点在于能够将所有安全和最佳实践规则作为结构化策略强制执行。

有许多开源策略引擎可以管理此问题，包括：

  • 开放策略代理 (OPA)（通过 Gatekeeper）：使用强大的 Rego 语言的通用策略引擎。
  • Kyverno：Kubernetes 原生引擎，可让您直接在 YAML 中编写策略（无需新语言）。
  • Polaris：一个策略引擎，专注于审核和自动执行最佳实践策略，以实现安全性、效率和可靠性。

最关键的一点是从一开始就启用这些策略引擎。如果您开始在基本集群上部署应用程序，然后稍后实施策略引擎，您将突然阻止不安全的部署。这将导致挫败感和阻力，因为开发人员已建立的（但不安全的）工作负载将不再被允许运行。

构建可靠、安全、高效的 Kubernetes

Kubernetes 是基础设施的游戏规则改变者，但可持续采用需要实践知识、持续投资以及在需要时寻求帮助的意愿。通过向那些大规模管理过数百个集群的人学习，并接受社区和专家的支持，组织可以构建强大、安全且经济高效的 Kubernetes 环境，从而促进创新而不是抑制创新。

要真正利用 Kubernetes 取得成功，无论是自行管理还是外包，组织都应该：

  • 预先投入时间进行安全、政策和用户权限管理。
  • 利用自动化工具和主动警报进行升级和附加维护
  • 在部署新集群或扩展 Kubernetes 使用之前验证业务需求
  • 通过资源、Slack 小组和开源工具文档寻求社区支持
  • 如果担心人才、时间或运营风险，请考虑托管解决方案

如果您的团队正在规划新的 Kubernetes 部署或正在努力解决生产稳定性问题，这些经验教训将为长期成功奠定基础。

如果您准备好消除运营难题并专注于价值，当内部资源有限时，组织还可以探索生态系统中的托管 Kubernetes 产品。
